2016-12-06.abstract: Polina Davydova was 3 when her family escaped the Nazis, and 53 when she left Russia. Now 77 and in failing health, she is grateful for the generosity of her new country.
2016-12-06.snippet: Polina Davydova was 3 when her family escaped the Nazis, and 53 when she left Russia. Now 77 and in failing health, she is grateful for the generosity of her new country.
2016-12-06.lead_paragraph: Under the cover of night, the family crowded into a wagon used to carry animals to flee the Nazi troops marching toward their hometown, Nalchik, in south-central Russia. It was 1942, and Polina Davydova’s father had returned from war wounded and requiring crutches to walk. He was now orchestrating the family’s escape farther south, to Derbent, a city on the Caspian Sea.
2016-12-06.headline_main: ‘I Want to Kiss America’: A Woman Who Fled Nazis, Then Russia, Makes a Life in Brooklyn

2016-12-06.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court is scheduled to hear arguments in Czyzewski v. Jevic Holding Corp. on Wednesday. At issue is whether a bankruptcy court can approve a settlement that distributes the debtor’s remaining assets in a way that could not be done under a Chapter 11 plan, at least not without the agreement of all creditors. In this case, some of the parties agreed to settle the case and to pay out the debtor’s cash to some of the creditors, but they intentionally skipped a class of creditors who were entitled to priority payment under the bankruptcy code.
2016-12-06.headline_main: Deciding Who Should Get First Dibs in Bankruptcy Liquidations

On Monday, Christopher Suprun, an elector from Texas, became the first Republican to say publicly that he won’t vote for Mr. Trump, who won his state. Mr. Suprun mentioned Gov. John Kasich of Ohio as a Republican he could support. But on Tuesday, Mr. Kasich said he wasn’t interested.

2016-12-06.snippet: Salvation Burger reopens, a longtime Parisian establishment pops up in SoHo, and other restaurant news.
2016-12-06.lead_paragraph: LORING PLACE At 43, the chef Dan Kluger, who has worked in the kitchens of many top names, was eager to be on his own and get his new restaurant off the ground. But compromises were not on his agenda, so it wound up taking two years. Even finding a name was, as he put it, “a struggle.” (It’s the street in the Fordham section of the Bronx where his father lived.) The spacious double storefront from 1848, on the increasingly attractive stretch of Eighth Street west of Fifth Avenue, looks as if it was worth the wait. Whitewashed brick walls contain a barroom and a bilevel dining room decorated simply, with a nod to midcentury modern. Mr. Kluger’s food is seasonal and market driven. And it builds on his experience working with chefs like Floyd Cardoz at Tabla, which shapes the flavors in his suckling pig and on his cauliflower with Indian seasonings, and Jean-Georges Vongerichten at ABC Kitchen, which inspired a vegetable focus on the menu. Local sourcing is so important to him that he’s grinding wheat from upstate for pasta extruded in-house. (Opens Saturday): 21 West Eighth Street, 212-388-1831, loringplacenyc.com.
2016-12-06.headline_main: Dan Kluger Builds on His Past, at Loring Place

2016-12-06.abstract: Paul Bloom is by no means making the case for heartlessness in his new book. He prefers a mixture of caring and detached cost-benefit analysis.
2016-12-06.snippet: Paul Bloom is by no means making the case for heartlessness in his new book. He prefers a mixture of caring and detached cost-benefit analysis.
2016-12-06.lead_paragraph: Paul Bloom’s new book, “Against Empathy: The Case for Rational Compassion,” is too highbrow to be a self-help or parenting manual, but parts of it could be. Its wingspan is too wide to be a simple guide to philanthropy, but parts of it could be that as well. And it’s a bit too clotted with caveats to be a seamless read, which is a shame, because it could have been, with more shaping.
2016-12-06.headline_main: Review: ‘Against Empathy,’ or the Right Way to Feel Someone’s Pain

2016-12-06.abstract: The opera will get a second chance at Teatro alla Scala in Milan, more than a century after its premiere met with catcalls and jeers.
2016-12-06.snippet: The opera will get a second chance at Teatro alla Scala in Milan, more than a century after its premiere met with catcalls and jeers.
2016-12-06.lead_paragraph: MILAN — The last time Puccini’s original version of “Madama Butterfly” was performed at the Teatro alla Scala here, it was over a century ago and it was a fiasco. The opera’s 1904 premiere was met with “grunts, growls, gibes, bellows, sneers,” one observer recalled, producing a “pandemonium, during which it was difficult to hear anything.”
2016-12-06.headline_main: Puccini’s ‘Madama Butterfly’ Returns to the Scene of a Disastrous Opening

2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: The Constitution gives presidents nearly unlimited authority to grant pardons and commute sentences — decisions that no future administration can reverse. Unfortunately, for most of his presidency, Barack Obama treated mercy as an afterthought. Even as thousands of men and women endured outrageously long sentences for low-level, nonviolent drug offenses as a result of the nation’s misguided drug war, Mr. Obama granted relief to only a tiny handful.

2016-12-07.snippet: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether to intervene when a parent is not responding to a child’s distress, what to do when a friend befriends your rapist’s ex and more.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: I was walking home from dinner with a friend one evening down a quiet residential street. Two boys, ages somewhere between 8 and 10, were biking down the road accompanied by a middle-aged woman. I assumed she was their mother. The front wheel of the second boy’s bike took a glancing blow from the curb and sent its rider straight onto the sidewalk. The boy, nursing what looked like a bruised knee and ego, held back tears.
2016-12-07.headline_main: Do You Get Involved When a Parent Treats a Child Badly?

2016-12-07.abstract: The pleasures of your own personal horror movie, on repeat.
2016-12-07.snippet: The pleasures of your own personal horror movie, on repeat.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: It is incredible to me how little I remember of what I was taught in high school. Whole subjects, entire years, have just dissolved. I need a calculator to do any kind of multiplication now. I recently tried to explain how electricity worked to a small child, and even she could tell I was making it up. But there are two things I recall with exceptional clarity: Napoleon’s retreat from Moscow (the hunger, the cold, the sleeping bags made of horse carcasses), and the opening soliloquy of “Richard III,” which I was required to memorize for English class at 16. I took this request very seriously, because I was not cool, and I spent many days slinking up and down the corridors hissing, “I am determined to prove a villain” to myself and narrowing my eyes. Though my ability to recite it remains useful as a party trick, that is not the reason it has remained lodged in my mind.
2016-12-07.headline_main: Letter of Recommendation: Anxiety Dreams

2016-12-07.snippet: As the oldest of us millennials begin to flee screaming from our 20s, where’s our “voice of a generation” novel?
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: As the oldest of us millennials begin to flee screaming from our 20s, it seems we may have forgotten something — where’s our “voice of a generation” novel? One of those all-important lifestyle accessories that supposedly speak to, and for, the sensibilities and circumstances of an entire American cohort? Not only is the current front-runner, Lena Dunham, not even a novelist, but her fictional avatar in “Girls” dismisses the idea of such a generational voice in the show’s very first episode.
2016-12-07.headline_main: Why There’s No ‘Millennial’ Novel

2016-12-07.abstract: Make meat pie for the holidays, and rejoice.
2016-12-07.snippet: Make meat pie for the holidays, and rejoice.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: There are a great many reasons to recommend the Christmas season in Francophone Canada and northern New England (let it snow, let it snow, let it snow!), but chief among them is tourtière. A tourtière is a pie, and one of the most delicious: a savory confection that can variously be packed with ground pork or a mixture of ground pork and game, encased in lardish dough. At highflier temples of Montreal gastronomy like Au Pied de Cochon (and at New York outposts, like M. Wells Steakhouse in Queens), you’ll find a great variety of meats in the tourtières, and occasionally slices of truffle or coins of foie gras. The classic accompaniment is a fruit ketchup or green-tomato relish, something piquant and bright against the rich, cinnamon-and-clove-scented taste of the meat, the vague porkiness of the dough.
2016-12-07.headline_main: A French-Canadian Christmas Carol

2016-12-07.abstract: People here are ecstatic about the phone call between the U.S. president-elect and Taiwan’s president. But is the U.S. really ready for change?
2016-12-07.snippet: People here are ecstatic about the phone call between the U.S. president-elect and Taiwan’s president. But is the U.S. really ready for change?
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — The atmosphere here is almost jubilant. The phone call last weekend from President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan to President-elect Donald J. Trump — the first contact between a Taiwanese president and an American president or president-elect since at least 1979 — has received rare bipartisan support here on this self-governing island off southern China. It was, many agree, a great thing for the country.
2016-12-07.headline_main: Taiwan Feels Forgotten. But Not by Trump.

2016-12-07.abstract: Those countries have both entered unusual comedies, but a raft of more traditional films are also in the running in a banner year for the category.
2016-12-07.snippet: Those countries have both entered unusual comedies, but a raft of more traditional films are also in the running in a banner year for the category.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: Every winter, Oscar watchers say that this or that category is especially competitive this year. But no competition at the Academy Awards is as reliably and inherently brutal as the one for best foreign-language film. For this globe-spanning category, each nation is allowed to submit one and only one film to represent its entire cinematic output for the year. That’s the case whether the country is France (which boasts more than 250 film productions in a year) or Yemen (where feature films are rare). For 2016, a record 85 countries successfully submitted films for the process of consideration as nominees. These will be winnowed to a shortlist, until finally, a mere five films will be announced as nominees on Jan. 24.
2016-12-07.headline_main: For Foreign-Language Oscar, a Robust Race With Germany and France Setting the Pace

2016-12-07.abstract: You can try to keep a low profile, but you can never choose invisibility. When the bigots decide to see you, they will see you.

2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — My father survived the killing fields of Cambodia, where he was threatened with having his tongue cut out with a sickle for speaking his native language, Teochew Chinese. When he and my pregnant mother arrived in Australia in 1980 and discovered that their new country encouraged them to maintain their language and culture, they were incredulous. My father named me Alice because he believed I was delivered into a Wonderland, a place that allowed for the full expression of human personality and potential.
2016-12-07.headline_main: Living With Racism in Australia

Now his cabinet is shaping up to be one of the most hostile in recent memory to issues affecting women, advocacy groups for women say. 2016-12-07.abstract: Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo, an all-male drag troupe, arrives at the Joyce.
2016-12-07.snippet: Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo, an all-male drag troupe, arrives at the Joyce.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: The point of drag, says RuPaul, an expert on the subject, is “to remind culture to not take itself seriously.” Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo, a sassy all-male drag troupe (Trocks, for short), has applied this ethos to the prim world of ballet for more than 40 years. After the company’s debut in 1974, critics applauded its smart satire of ballerinas and inherent commentary on the performance of femininity. But hidden in all that jest is great reverence for the art form and its history, and audiences keep coming back — when else can you laugh at the ballet?
2016-12-07.headline_main: Brawny Chests and Classic Tutus

2016-12-07.abstract: Rez Abbasi’s all-star project, Invocation, includes the pianist Vijay Iyer and will be playing the Asia Society.
2016-12-07.snippet: Rez Abbasi’s all-star project, Invocation, includes the pianist Vijay Iyer and will be playing the Asia Society.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: The guitarist Rez Abbasi, who was born in Pakistan but raised in Southern California, approaches the process of cultural fusion with deep seriousness but also a spirit of play. In his own groups — and with cooperatives like the Indo-Pak Coalition, an excellent trio featuring Rudresh Mahanthappa on alto saxophone and Dan Weiss on drums and percussion — he adds his dynamic, brisk voice to the modern-jazz dialect. Mr. Abbasi’s band Invocation, which features Mr. Mahanthappa and Mr. Weiss along with the pianist Vijay Iyer, the bassist Johannes Weidenmüller and the cellist Elizabeth Means, taps into the complex classical traditions of South Indian Carnatic music. On Thursday, Dec. 15, and Friday at Asia Society, they’ll play music from “Unfiltered Universe,” which Mr. Abbasi will release next year, completing a trilogy of albums by the band. (212-517-2742; asiasociety.org.)
2016-12-07.headline_main: A Guitarist’s Cultural Fusion, With a Touch of Play

2016-12-07.abstract: “Syria: A Living History,” at the Aga Khan Museum in Toronto focuses on the country’s past and present through 48 objects.
2016-12-07.snippet: “Syria: A Living History,” at the Aga Khan Museum in Toronto focuses on the country’s past and present through 48 objects.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: After years of civil war, and with one of its most venerable cities, Aleppo, under threat of obliteration, Syria is for many little more than a 21st-century nightmare, its glorious past lost and forgotten. The exhibition “Syria: A Living History,” at the Aga Khan Museum in Toronto, is here to remind us of that past. The show features just 48 objects, but it encompasses centuries, and much of the work is choice. The earliest piece, a stone sculpture that looks abstract except for two pairs of staring eyes, dates from around 3200 B.C. An exquisitely carved ivory lion’s head from the eighth or ninth century B.C. has roots in Near Eastern visual traditions shared with Anatolia and Mesopotamia. Christian, Jewish and Islamic influences also came into play and mingled. Throughout all of this, there were periods of murderous struggle. More remarkable, there were even longer stretches of multicultural peace. By closing with contemporary Syrian works, the show suggests that, against all present evidence, there could be peace again. (Through Feb. 26.)
2016-12-07.headline_main: Syria’s Murderous Struggle, and Multicultural Peace

2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: My 11-part collection of favorite performances might cover a lot of ground (movies, television, sports, the web) and include feats of both acting and core strength, but they all made me happy even when they raised my blood pressure or made me cry. Not included: Krisha Fairchild, the star of Trey Edward Shults’s movie “Krisha,” and Beyoncé at the Super Bowl, because I’ve said my piece (many times over!) about how outrageously good they are. I left the casts of “Moonlight” and “Atlanta” alone for pretty much the same reason. And I’m also sad for missing Jake Gyllenhaal in “Sunday in the Park With George,” Nina Stemme in “Tristan und Isolde” and Kathleen Battle make up with the Met. Word on the street is I should feel sorry for myself, and I do. Here’s what I did see, though:

2016-12-07.abstract: Karl Lagerfeld presented a collection yesterday in the grand old hotel where Coco Chanel had lived for decades.
2016-12-07.snippet: Karl Lagerfeld presented a collection yesterday in the grand old hotel where Coco Chanel had lived for decades.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: Gabrielle “Coco” Chanel spent her life at the Paris Ritz — a fact much-publicized, mythologized and commercialized over her lifetime, and beyond. She died there on Jan. 10, 1971. And, in a manner, she was reborn there, too — as the great Parisian couturière, rather than the orphan girl from Saumur. Chanel was at the very height of her fame and influence when she took up residence at the Ritz permanently in 1937. She had already taken over the stretch of buildings Chanel still occupies, down the Rue Cambon, which runs along the back of the hotel itself, and at that point employed 4,000 people. Her multiple suites at the Ritz served as a symbol of her success.
2016-12-07.headline_main: Chanel’s Ritzy Ode to Parisian Society

2016-12-07.abstract: The 21st Century Cures Act, already passed by the House, was backed by an unusual alliance of pharmaceutical companies and patients desperate for cures.
2016-12-07.snippet: The 21st Century Cures Act, already passed by the House, was backed by an unusual alliance of pharmaceutical companies and patients desperate for cures.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate approved complex health care legislation on Wednesday that would increase funding for disease research, address weaknesses in the nation’s mental health systems and vastly alter the regulatory system for drugs and medical devices. The vote sealed a final legislative victory for President Obama, who strongly supported the bill against objections from many liberal Democrats and consumer groups.
2016-12-07.headline_main: Sweeping Health Measure, Backed by Obama, Passes Senate

2016-12-07.abstract: A seething “Elektra.” Thomas Adès’s “The Exterminating Angel.” And who can forget those 100 bleating sheep at the Park Avenue Armory?
2016-12-07.snippet: A seething “Elektra.” Thomas Adès’s “The Exterminating Angel.” And who can forget those 100 bleating sheep at the Park Avenue Armory?
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: ‘ELEKTRA’ The fearless French director Patrice Chéreau died at 68 in 2013, a few months after his searing production of Strauss’s “Elektra” had its premiere at the Aix-en-Provence Festival in France. The Metropolitan Opera, one of the co-producers of this seething and psychologically piercing staging, presented it in April with a matchless cast headed by the gleaming soprano Nina Stemme in the title role. Esa-Pekka Salonen conducted the score with a composer’s insight into its complexities and splendors. It was an immediate Met milestone. [Read the review]
2016-12-07.headline_main: The Best Classical Music of 2016

2016-12-07.abstract: Chicago turned Jorge Soler, a young, power-hitting outfielder, into a replacement for Aroldis Chapman, a free agent expected to get a big contract.
2016-12-07.snippet: Chicago turned Jorge Soler, a young, power-hitting outfielder, into a replacement for Aroldis Chapman, a free agent expected to get a big contract.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: NATIONAL HARBOR, Md. — No pitcher in baseball history has gotten the final out of the World Series for two different teams. Wade Davis closed out the 2015 championship for the Kansas City Royals. In the master plan of the Chicago Cubs, he will soon do the same for them.
2016-12-07.headline_main: Cubs Parlay Their Depth Into a Closer, Wade Davis

2016-12-07.abstract: The actor doesn’t miss his castle in Ireland. Just give him a scarf, a guitar and his trusty terrier, and he’s perfectly content.
2016-12-07.snippet: The actor doesn’t miss his castle in Ireland. Just give him a scarf, a guitar and his trusty terrier, and he’s perfectly content.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: Jeremy Irons owns a pied-à-terre in London, a house in Oxfordshire and a 15th-century castle in Cork, Ireland, painted a color that complaining neighbors have called pink.
2016-12-07.headline_main: Home Is Anywhere Jeremy Irons Drapes His Scarf

2016-12-07.abstract: Some employers still impose a New Year’s deadline for exhausting the balance of a flexible health spending account or forfeiting what’s left.
2016-12-07.snippet: Some employers still impose a New Year’s deadline for exhausting the balance of a flexible health spending account or forfeiting what’s left.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: WHILE rules for flexible health spending accounts have themselves become more flexible, some employees may still have a New Year’s deadline for spending their balances.
2016-12-07.headline_main: Still Have a Health-Account Balance? Time for That 11th-Hour Eye Exam

2016-12-07.abstract: The year offered a stirring display of Odissi from the Nrityagram Dance Ensemble and triumphs from the choreographer Alexei Ratmansky.
2016-12-07.snippet: The year offered a stirring display of Odissi from the Nrityagram Dance Ensemble and triumphs from the choreographer Alexei Ratmansky.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: In a year that brought its political and cultural troubles, it’s heartening to note how diverse kinds of dance made culture itself seem bright. Take Odissi (from the state of Odisha, on India’s east coast), which, though one of the world’s oldest dance genres, came close to extinction in the mid-20th century. Now, however, it often seems astoundingly vital: No dance idiom is more overwhelmingly sensuous.
2016-12-07.headline_main: The Best Dance of 2016

2016-12-07.abstract: Formerly Dempsey’s Pub, the tavern offers small craft beers, Irish stew and a more polished atmosphere.
2016-12-07.snippet: Formerly Dempsey’s Pub, the tavern offers small craft beers, Irish stew and a more polished atmosphere.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: As the East Village continues to get fancier, demand for scruffy Irish pubs inevitably drops in favor of more polished ones. Enter the Gray Mare, which has traded in the college-friendly vibes of its predecessor, Dempsey’s Pub, for a more continental, curated experience.
2016-12-07.headline_main: The Gray Mare, a Polished Pub for a Fancier East Village

2016-12-07.abstract: Ibanez Ambrose, 2, and Scylee Vayoh Ambrose, 1, died in temporary housing for the homeless after being severely burned, the authorities said.
2016-12-07.snippet: Ibanez Ambrose, 2, and Scylee Vayoh Ambrose, 1, died in temporary housing for the homeless after being severely burned, the authorities said.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: Two young sisters living in temporary housing for homeless people in the South Bronx died on Wednesday after being severely burned, apparently by steam from a radiator in their apartment, the authorities said.

2016-12-07.abstract: Trump refuses to take responsibility for giving a platform to white supremacists.
2016-12-07.snippet: Trump refuses to take responsibility for giving a platform to white supremacists.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: Whatever kind of president Donald J. Trump turns out to be, he will surely be no Harry S. Truman. Instead of the sign that Truman kept on his desk declaring that “The Buck Stops Here,” Trump should get one that says, “Don’t Blame Me” — embellished perhaps with the phony coat of arms he plastered on his Scottish golf course.
2016-12-07.headline_main: Donald Trump’s Big Idea: Don’t Blame Me

2016-12-07.abstract: Gov. Terry Branstad of Iowa spoke after he was tapped by President-elect Donald J. Trump to be ambassador to China. A spokesman for the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs also welcomed the pick of Mr. Branstad.

2016-12-07.abstract: The designer, marking 35 years since her first runway show in 1981, is the subject of a Lincoln Center Tribute.
2016-12-07.snippet: The designer, marking 35 years since her first runway show in 1981, is the subject of a Lincoln Center Tribute.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: Carolina Herrera has had quite a year. The fashion designer, best known early in her career for the wedding dresses she designed for celebrity clients like Caroline Kennedy and now the leader of a $1.2 billion global empire, recently marked her 35-year career with a book party in Manhattan that attracted such celebrities as Serena Williams and Priyanka Chopra; followed by another commemorative event in Madrid, where the host was the American ambassador to Spain, James Costos; and a trip down to Dallas, where she was honored by Neiman Marcus with an award for “distinguished service in the field of fashion.”
2016-12-07.headline_main: The Fashion World Honors Carolina Herrera With a Little Help From Diana Ross

2016-12-07.abstract: The fashion designer was given the Women’s Leadership Award by the Lincoln Center Corporate Fund, followed by a 20-minute performance by Ms. Ross.

2016-12-07.abstract: A look at the collection “Bresson on Bresson: Interviews 1943-1983” and Robert Bresson’s own “Notes on the Cinematograph.”
2016-12-07.snippet: A look at the collection “Bresson on Bresson: Interviews 1943-1983” and Robert Bresson’s own “Notes on the Cinematograph.”

2016-12-07.headline_main: Review: Bresson and the Elliptical Economies of a Master Filmmaker

2016-12-07.abstract: In a city that lacks affordable spaces, artists and innovators found a haven and community in an Oakland warehouse.
2016-12-07.snippet: In a city that lacks affordable spaces, artists and innovators found a haven and community in an Oakland warehouse.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — This city is my America. We in Oakland pride ourselves on our inclination to question and to disobey, to establish havens and battlegrounds for those brave and tender hearted enough to resist conformity.
2016-12-07.headline_main: The Ghost Ship: It Could Have Been Any One of Us

2016-12-07.abstract: Though Bob Dylan won’t attend the Nobel Prize dinner in Stockholm, the city has one unassailable tie to him: Izzy Young, who promoted his debut New York show in 1961.
2016-12-07.snippet: Though Bob Dylan won’t attend the Nobel Prize dinner in Stockholm, the city has one unassailable tie to him: Izzy Young, who promoted his debut New York show in 1961.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM — Bob Dylan won’t be visiting Sweden this week to accept the Nobel Prize in Literature, though he has sent a speech in his absence. The news of his no-show at the ceremony on Saturday disappointed fans — as well as one resident here who has old ties to rock’s poet laureate: Israel Goodman Young, the man who gave Mr. Dylan his first New York concert.
2016-12-07.headline_main: Settled in Sweden, the Man Who First Booked Dylan

2016-12-07.abstract: The Amazon series created a work about Amy Fisher, the 1990s tabloid sensation, with help from the composer Nico Muhly.
2016-12-07.snippet: The Amazon series created a work about Amy Fisher, the 1990s tabloid sensation, with help from the composer Nico Muhly.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: Her crime spawned tabloid coverage, quickie books and three made-for-TV movies. Now Amy Fisher, who became known as the Long Island Lolita  nearly a quarter of a century ago when she shot her lover’s wife, has inspired something rarer: a made-for-TV aria.
2016-12-07.headline_main: An Aria for the Long Island Lolita on ‘Mozart in the Jungle’

2016-12-07.abstract: The Manhattan developer DDG not only puts up apartments but also builds the staging for operas, free.
2016-12-07.snippet: The Manhattan developer DDG not only puts up apartments but also builds the staging for operas, free.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: On a dreary afternoon in late November, inside a cavernous former shipworks at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, Michael Zaragoza was busy dipping shredded burlap sacks into buckets of gritty plaster. He then draped the stiffened sheets over a plywood platform, creating a craggy stage for Verdi’s “Macbeth,” the 1847 work that LoftOpera presents here starting Thursday. Nearby, Alyshia Taboas cut into bright blue sheets of roof insulation, her utility knife forming the notches and ridges onto which Mr. Zaragoza would drape his rocky fabric.
2016-12-07.headline_main: Designing Luxury Condos, and Operas, Too

2016-12-07.abstract: Four newly reimagined institutions, where creative types once worked and partied.
2016-12-07.snippet: Four newly reimagined institutions, where creative types once worked and partied.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: Four newly reimagined institutions, where creative types once worked and partied.
2016-12-07.headline_main: Drinking and Eating Like Old Writers and Artists

2016-12-07.abstract: The World Anti-Doping Agency, the primary international watchdog on the use of performance-enhancing substances, will publish the results of an investigation Friday morning.
2016-12-07.snippet: The World Anti-Doping Agency, the primary international watchdog on the use of performance-enhancing substances, will publish the results of an investigation Friday morning.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: Detailed accounts of state-sponsored doping in Russia have unsettled global sports this year. On Friday morning, another investigation into Russian doping will wrap up.
2016-12-07.headline_main: What’s at Stake as an Inquiry Into Russian Doping Wraps Up

2016-12-07.abstract: The actor Colman Domingo spoke about how the Nate Parker film’s awards prospects have been damaged because of the 1999 rape accusation against Mr. Parker.
2016-12-07.snippet: The actor Colman Domingo spoke about how the Nate Parker film’s awards prospects have been damaged because of the 1999 rape accusation against Mr. Parker.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: At Fox Searchlight’s holiday party in New York last week, the Bagger bumped into a couple of stars from two of the studio’s splashiest 2016 productions: one of the films soared to great heights, while the other crashed to an unimagined low.
2016-12-07.headline_main: A Casualty of ‘The Birth of a Nation’ Controversy Speaks Out

2016-12-07.abstract: The artist spent a year hosting a party each week in his studio, with themes ranging from Prom to Autopsy to Paintball.
2016-12-07.snippet: The artist spent a year hosting a party each week in his studio, with themes ranging from Prom to Autopsy to Paintball.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: The artist spent a year hosting a party each week in his studio, with themes ranging from Prom to Autopsy to Paintball.
2016-12-07.headline_main: Ryan McGinness’s ‘50 Parties’

2016-12-07.abstract: In 2009 and 2010, Ryan McGinness hosted 50 themed events at his studio, and photographed them for a new book. The project got a little out of control.
2016-12-07.snippet: In 2009 and 2010, Ryan McGinness hosted 50 themed events at his studio, and photographed them for a new book. The project got a little out of control.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: Between 2009 and 2010, the artist Ryan McGinness embarked on an endurance performance in which he hosted one party a week in his New York studio for 50 consecutive weeks. (Fifty-one, if you count the practice party that kicked things off.) This turned out to be a more brutal exercise than initially intended. Last week, during Art Basel Miami Beach, McGinness sat at a table at the Standard Hotel and reflected on this experience. It was “harrowing and stressful,” he said. “Yeah, it was awful. After the second party I was ready to throw in the towel.”
2016-12-07.headline_main: One Artist Threw a Party a Week for an Entire Year

2016-12-07.abstract: In our new weekly visual exploration of dance, we examine Reggie Wilson’s latest work, as performed by Yeman Brown.
2016-12-07.snippet: In our new weekly visual exploration of dance, we examine Reggie Wilson’s latest work, as performed by Yeman Brown.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: #SpeakingInDance is a new weekly visual exploration of dance. Follow us on Instagram: @nytimes.
2016-12-07.headline_main: Reggie Wilson’s ‘Citizen’: Sheer Repetition and Speed

2016-12-07.abstract: The mayor-elect, Marcelo Crivella, is promoting the new idea as a way to bolster tourism in the crime-plagued city.
2016-12-07.snippet: The mayor-elect, Marcelo Crivella, is promoting the new idea as a way to bolster tourism in the crime-plagued city.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The mayor-elect of Rio de Janeiro is promoting a new idea to bolster tourism in his crime-plagued city: levying a new tax on tourists, then using the proceeds to reimburse visitors who are mugged.
2016-12-07.headline_main: Rio Proposal: Tax Tourists to Help Them When They Are Mugged

2016-12-07.abstract: The musician, whose name is Donald Glover, delivers an unabashed throwback to the sounds of R&B before hip-hop came along.
2016-12-07.snippet: The musician, whose name is Donald Glover, delivers an unabashed throwback to the sounds of R&B before hip-hop came along.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: Donald Glover — actor, comedian, writer, producer, rapper, songwriter — has set himself a complex cultural project: to both embody current African-American culture and reveal it to the wider world. He has done that on albums under his musical alias, Childish Gambino, and also as the driving force of “Atlanta,” the superb TV series on FX on which he is an executive producer, writer and actor, presenting a street-level corrective to the glamour-and-guns hip-hop fantasies of “Empire.”
2016-12-07.headline_main: Childish Gambino’s ‘Awaken, My Love!’ Sounds Like the 1970s

2016-12-07.abstract: Amos Oz’s “Judas” reconsiders the label of “traitor.”
2016-12-07.snippet: Amos Oz’s “Judas” reconsiders the label of “traitor.”
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: JUDASBy Amos OzTranslated by Nicholas de Lange305 pp. Houghton Mifflin Harcourt. $25.
2016-12-07.headline_main: Judas, Jesus and Politics: Amos Oz’s New Novel

2016-12-07.abstract: The recovery of a woman with advanced colon cancer, after treatment with cells from her own immune system, may help doctors develop new treatments for other patients.
2016-12-07.snippet: The recovery of a woman with advanced colon cancer, after treatment with cells from her own immune system, may help doctors develop new treatments for other patients.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: The remarkable recovery of a woman with advanced colon cancer, after treatment with cells from her own immune system, may lead to new options for thousands of other patients with colon or pancreatic cancer, researchers are reporting.
2016-12-07.headline_main: 1 Patient, 7 Tumors and 100 Billion Cells Equal 1 Striking Recovery

2016-12-07.abstract: He writes. He acts. He developed an app. And he wears clothes.
2016-12-07.snippet: He writes. He acts. He developed an app. And he wears clothes.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: As if working on a laugh line until it’s just right, B. J. Novak has refined his look over the years. The actor and writer, who made his name on the sitcom “The Office” before going on to write and direct episodes of the show, appears this month with Michael Keaton in “The Founder,” a film about Ray Kroc of McDonald’s.
2016-12-07.headline_main: The Straightforward Style of the Polymathic B.J. Novak

2016-12-07.abstract: Coach celebrates its re-emergence with a flagship on Fifth Avenue, featuring a ceiling conveyor belt, an in-store workshop and a 12-foot dinosaur.
2016-12-07.snippet: Coach celebrates its re-emergence with a flagship on Fifth Avenue, featuring a ceiling conveyor belt, an in-store workshop and a 12-foot dinosaur.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: Stuart Vevers, the Coach creative director, has dug up more than a few great ideas since taking over the brand in 2013, but his best has been dinosaur bones.

2016-12-07.abstract: In Declan Donnellan’s production at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the homicidal protagonist’s motives are all too clear.
2016-12-07.snippet: In Declan Donnellan’s production at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the homicidal protagonist’s motives are all too clear.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: “The Winter’s Tale” has been rewritten as the diary of a madman. Much of the first half of Cheek by Jowl’s viscerally charged interpretation of this strange Shakespeare romance, at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is presented through the perspective of one seriously demented king.
2016-12-07.headline_main: Review: In This ‘Winter’s Tale,’ the King Is Insane. It’s as Simple as That.

2016-12-07.abstract: This play by Hillary Bettis, about a fictitious Florida tourist attraction, sits uneasily somewhere between gritty naturalism and magical realism.
2016-12-07.snippet: This play by Hillary Bettis, about a fictitious Florida tourist attraction, sits uneasily somewhere between gritty naturalism and magical realism.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: Much of Hilary Bettis’s relentlessly lurid “Alligator,” produced by New Georges and the Sol Project, is set in and around the pit at the Ever ’Gator Ranch, a fictitious Florida tourist attraction. People enter this pit to wrestle with their terrors, desires, disappointments — and the occasional gator. Don’t be surprised if you find yourself rooting for the reptile.
2016-12-07.headline_main: Review: ‘Alligator’ Wallows in a Lurid Florida Pit of Sex and Murder

2016-12-07.abstract: In “A Path to Peace,” two American officials, George J. Mitchell and Alon Sachar, recall Israeli-Palestinian negotiations.

2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: A PATH TO PEACEA Brief History of Israeli-Palestinian Negotiations and a Way Forward in the Middle EastBy George J. Mitchell and Alon Sachar258 pp. Simon & Schuster. $26.
2016-12-07.headline_main: George J. Mitchell on Israeli-Palestinian Diplomacy

2016-12-07.abstract: How a comic book aficionado uses her own body as a canvas.
2016-12-07.snippet: How a comic book aficionado uses her own body as a canvas.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: Comic book enthusiasts have been transforming themselves into their favorite characters for decades using mass-produced costumes or custom outfits. This dress-up, known as “cosplay,” has become a celebrated part of fandom. But Kay Pike, 28, is a comic book fan with a different approach: Call it cospaint.
2016-12-07.headline_main: She Brings Comic Book Characters to Life

2016-12-07.abstract: Among the figures he knew as owner of the Phoenix Book Shop in Greenwich Village were Gertrude Stein, W.H. Auden, William S. Burroughs, Edward Albee, Allen Ginsberg and Patti Smith.
2016-12-07.snippet: Among the figures he knew as owner of the Phoenix Book Shop in Greenwich Village were Gertrude Stein, W.H. Auden, William S. Burroughs, Edward Albee, Allen Ginsberg and Patti Smith.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: One evening in 1959, a well-read man walked into a small bookstore in Greenwich Village where he often shopped. He knew the owner well enough to say, “You haven’t sold me a book in weeks.”
2016-12-07.headline_main: Robert A. Wilson, 94, Whose Bookshop Was Poets’ Sanctuary, Dies

2016-12-07.snippet: Personalize it at Intermix and Gucci, shop for winter finds at Dover Street Market and, when you’re exhausted, get a pick-me-up at Rent the Runway.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: It’s beginning to look a lot like Christmas shopping season. On Thursday, Rachel Comey will host a holiday bazaar with perfect hostess gifts like a double tube vase ($450). Fifteen percent of proceeds will benefit the American Civil Liberties Union. At 95 Crosby Street.

2016-12-07.abstract: Seph Skerritt started Proper Cloth as an online store for custom men’s shirts. Now he has a large showroom to go with it.
2016-12-07.snippet: Seph Skerritt started Proper Cloth as an online store for custom men’s shirts. Now he has a large showroom to go with it.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: Seph Skerritt bought his first custom shirt in Shanghai, during an internship after college. It got him thinking why the same service wasn’t available to a wider audience. “I told them exactly what I wanted, and that’s what I got,” he said.

2016-12-07.abstract: A soft-spoken Edgar M. Welch described from jail his thoughts leading up to his decision to fire a military-style assault rifle inside the pizzeria.
2016-12-07.snippet: A soft-spoken Edgar M. Welch described from jail his thoughts leading up to his decision to fire a military-style assault rifle inside the pizzeria.
2016-12-07.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Edgar M. Welch, 28, of Salisbury, N.C., was arrested Sunday after firing a gun inside a pizza restaurant in Washington as he investigated false claims in online articles that the pizzeria was at the center of a child sex slave ring, the police said. No one was injured by the gunfire, and Mr. Welch surrendered peacefully. The pizzeria, Comet Ping Pong, had been swept into a conspiracy theory, which linked the supposed ring to Hillary Clinton, because its owner had corresponded with the Clinton campaign about a fund-raising dinner.
2016-12-07.headline_main: The Comet Ping Pong Gunman Answers Our Reporter’s Questions

2016-12-07.abstract: The 30-year-old virtuoso has been bewitching the front row of catwalk shows and classical music audiences alike.

2016-12-07.headline_main: The Violinist Charlie Siem Strikes a High Note in Fashion

2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: “Designated Survivor” is moving at two simultaneous but very different rhythms. The F.B.I. agent Hannah Wells has raced through reveal after shocking reveal while President Kirkman has stumbled after her, wading through bureaucracy and banging his head fruitlessly on the nation’s largest mysteries. The show’s double-barreled plotline seemed to promise a powerful pact between the two — if Kirkman could just get his act together. But right as he uncovers a huge piece of evidence to accelerate that connection, the show takes a sharp left turn.

2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: Soaring use of e-cigarettes among young people “is now a major public health concern,” according to a report published Thursday from the United States Surgeon General. It is the first comprehensive look on the subject from the nation’s highest public-health authority, and it finds that e-cigarettes are now the most commonly used tobacco product among youths, surpassing tobacco cigarettes.

2016-12-08.abstract: The Times critics Wesley Morris and A.O. Scott discuss how the year’s best acting showed us two kinds of power: One found in professional experience, the other in the experience of being alive.
2016-12-08.snippet: The Times critics Wesley Morris and A.O. Scott discuss how the year’s best acting showed us two kinds of power: One found in professional experience, the other in the experience of being alive.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: WESLEY MORRIS: What is it about watching someone become someone else that has been so mesmerizing for so many people for so long? What is it about a person’s becoming his or her ultimate self that we can’t resist? It’s all-powerful, all-consuming stuff. In life, that consumption can be dangerous. But in art, I want my mind controlled by that power. I want an actor’s skill, intelligence, energy, body and face to overtake me. I love the movie magic of no longer seeing an actor — or especially a star — but a person.
2016-12-08.headline_main: The Year’s Most Captivating Film Performances

2016-12-08.snippet: The incoming president has a substantial opportunity to shift the entire federal judiciary to the right.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: In a recent issue of Judicature, an academic journal for judges published by Duke University Law School, Timothy J. Corrigan, a federal district judge in Florida, reflected on “the most multifaceted, emotional, and challenging task a judge performs ” — sentencing convicted criminal defendants. Judge Corrigan wrote about the broad discretion that district judges exercise, describing experiences from his 14 years on the bench that were both heart-rending (tear-stained letters from young children begging mercy for their parents) and hair-raising (an assassination attempt). The article’s title, across the journal’s front cover, said it all: “Who Appointed Me God?”
2016-12-08.headline_main: Under Trump, the Federal Courts Will Be Up for Grabs

2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: The trustees of Cooperstown, N.Y., hardly expected their village (population 1,834) to emerge as a flash point in a national debate over climate change and socially responsible investing.

2016-12-08.abstract: The settlement with the National Music Publishers’ Association, a trade group, is said to be worth more than $40 million.

2016-12-08.abstract: Shareholders should be willing to sell near an offer price rather than wait to see a merger close
2016-12-08.snippet: Shareholders should be willing to sell near an offer price rather than wait to see a merger close
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: A spate of corporate deal remorse has left investors regretful, too. Abbott Laboratories on Wednesday cited “material adverse events” in a legal bid to end its $5.8 billion takeover of the medical test maker Alere. Similar tensions have arisen in mergers involving Yahoo, Williams and Cigna. They all help make the case for heightened shareholder skepticism.
2016-12-08.headline_main: Investor’s Remorse Follows Buyer’s Remorse as Big Deals Fall Apart

2016-12-08.abstract: The killing of Aidan O’Driscoll, known as “the Beast,” in the southwest city of Cork was the first gangland-style execution in Ireland in four years.

2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — The police are investigating the gangland-style killing of a former senior figure in an Irish Republican Army splinter group who was ambushed from behind by two masked gunmen in the southwest city of Cork.

2016-12-08.abstract: Also, nosy questions from competitive friends, when a gift check goes uncashed and whether to comment on an office mate’s attire.
2016-12-08.snippet: Also, nosy questions from competitive friends, when a gift check goes uncashed and whether to comment on an office mate’s attire.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: Last week, a woman I barely know came up to me reluctantly to tell me that, according to her teenage daughter, my teenage son is pretty much friendless and is being bullied at school for being a “freak.” I had no idea, but I can see that he is anxious and socially awkward. The woman made me promise that I would not ascribe any information to her daughter. Should I speak to my son? If so, how do I broach the subject without her story?
2016-12-08.headline_main: I Learned My Teenage Son Is Being Bullied. Should I Tell Him?

2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: NBC’s live production of “Hairspray” had nine million viewers on Wednesday night, making it the lowest-rated of the network’s four live musical events over the past three years.

2016-12-08.abstract: A Chinese paleontologist’s discovery in an amber market is offering new insights into the evolution of feathers.
2016-12-08.snippet: A Chinese paleontologist’s discovery in an amber market is offering new insights into the evolution of feathers.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: While most paleontologists dig up prehistoric bones from the ground, Lida Xing hunts for fossils in the amber markets of Myanmar. In 2015, he made a remarkable find: Trapped in what looked like golden glass was the feathered tail of a dinosaur.
2016-12-08.headline_main: That Thing With Feathers Trapped in Amber? It Was a Dinosaur Tail

2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: The British photographer opened her first solo show in Amsterdam this month.
2016-12-08.headline_main: Harley Weir’s “Boundaries”

2016-12-08.abstract: The photographer Harley Weir — who shot her first fashion editorial for a magazine at age 17 — opened her first solo show in Amsterdam this month.
2016-12-08.snippet: The photographer Harley Weir — who shot her first fashion editorial for a magazine at age 17 — opened her first solo show in Amsterdam this month.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: Whether shooting a portfolio of Senegalese people at work and play or young women in varying states of undress, the images taken by the British photographer Harley Weir, 28, capture unguarded moments with an honest eye. In “Boundaries,” her first solo show — which opened at Amsterdam’s FOAM Museum earlier this month — Weir’s photos draw the viewer into proximity with her subjects, so that skin and emotion are magnified. “There’s definitely a sense of intimacy to my work,” she says. “That’s the strongest element.”
2016-12-08.headline_main: A Young Photographer’s Intimate, Dreamlike Images

2016-12-08.abstract: You thought he was a movie star. But he has been a guru all along.

2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: Matthew McConaughey has two movies out this month. In one, he gives voice to an animated koala who organizes a singing contest. In the other, he plays a schlubby dreamer turned jungle adventurer.
2016-12-08.headline_main: The Tao of Matthew McConaughey

2016-12-08.abstract: The tragedy underscored the challenges Mayor Bill de Blasio faces in addressing an issue where even the potential solutions can create further problems.
2016-12-08.snippet: The tragedy underscored the challenges Mayor Bill de Blasio faces in addressing an issue where even the potential solutions can create further problems.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York took responsibility for the city’s worsening homelessness problem, saying, “I own it.” Less than two hours later, his pledge took on tragic implications, when two young sisters were burned to death in the South Bronx by radiator steam in city-financed housing for the homeless.
2016-12-08.headline_main: Sisters’ Deaths Reveal Strains in City’s Efforts to Tackle Homelessness

2016-12-08.snippet: Quarterback Carson Palmer and running back Jeremy Hill are good starts, as is the Jets’ Matt Forte, if you’re feeling brave.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: The Sablich brothers have provided award-winning fantasy football advice for The New York Times since 2010. See their weekly player rankings and visit 5thDownFantasy.com for more fantasy analysis. You can also ask them questions through their Twitter account, @5thdownfantasy.
2016-12-08.headline_main: Fantasy Football: Players to Start in Week 14

2016-12-08.abstract: Robert Stackowitz, who fled a Georgia prison nearly 50 years ago, was discovered earlier this year living under an alias in Sherman, Conn.
2016-12-08.snippet: Robert Stackowitz, who fled a Georgia prison nearly 50 years ago, was discovered earlier this year living under an alias in Sherman, Conn.

2016-12-08.headline_main: Georgia Fugitive, Who Settled Quietly in Connecticut, Dies at 71

2016-12-08.abstract: Geometric abstraction from Latin America figures prominently in Ms. Fontanals-Cisneros’s collection of some 3,300 works.
2016-12-08.snippet: Geometric abstraction from Latin America figures prominently in Ms. Fontanals-Cisneros’s collection of some 3,300 works.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Art fans often talk about collecting in terms of first love. The Cuban-born Ella Fontanals-Cisneros says she fell hard in the 1980s for a work in Jesús Rafael Soto’s “Vibration” series, featuring panels painted with black-and-white parallel lines juxtaposed with wood and wire.
2016-12-08.headline_main: In Ella Fontanals-Cisneros’s Collection, Latin American Roots Run Deep

2016-12-08.headline_main: Government Shutdown Looms Over Stopgap Spending Measure

2016-12-08.abstract: A look at the life of Mr. Glenn, the first American to orbit the Earth and a 24-year senator from Ohio.
2016-12-08.snippet: A look at the life of Mr. Glenn, the first American to orbit the Earth and a 24-year senator from Ohio.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: A look at the life of Mr. Glenn, the first American to orbit the Earth and a 24-year senator from Ohio.
2016-12-08.headline_main: John Glenn: A Patriot in Space and Politics

2016-12-08.abstract: Mr. Glenn was a symbol of the space age as the first American to orbit Earth, then became a national political figure representing Ohio in the Senate.
2016-12-08.snippet: Mr. Glenn was a symbol of the space age as the first American to orbit Earth, then became a national political figure representing Ohio in the Senate.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: John Glenn, a freckle-faced son of Ohio who was hailed as a national hero and a symbol of the space age as the first American to orbit Earth, then became a national political figure for 24 years in the Senate, died on Thursday in Columbus, Ohio. He was 95.
2016-12-08.headline_main: John Glenn, American Hero of the Space Age, Dies at 95

2016-12-08.abstract: A swordsman has grown tired of his work and his love in this remake of “Death Duel,” a nod to the Chinese magic-and-martial arts genre wuxia.
2016-12-08.snippet: A swordsman has grown tired of his work and his love in this remake of “Death Duel,” a nod to the Chinese magic-and-martial arts genre wuxia.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: Stuffed with demon warriors, vamping concubines and overblown acrobatics, Derek Yee’s “Sword Master” packs a lot into its 105 minutes. A remake of Chor Yuen’s “Death Duel” (1977), this nostalgic nod to the Chinese magic-and-martial arts genre known as wuxia mixes love story and clan war with equal amounts of silliness and heart.
2016-12-08.headline_main: Review: You Quit? Think Again, ‘Sword Master’

2016-12-08.abstract: This sweet-natured coming-of-age movie is perhaps more complicated than most by having characters whose sexual orientations are in flux.
2016-12-08.snippet: This sweet-natured coming-of-age movie is perhaps more complicated than most by having characters whose sexual orientations are in flux.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: “Slash” opens with a science-fiction sequence that would fit comfortably into “Dune.” It’s quickly revealed to have sprung from the mind of Neil (Michael Johnston), a 15-year-old who writes erotic fan fiction. The twist is that the muscular hero and villain abruptly cease fighting and begin making out. Neil, who is questioning his sexuality, is teased at school, particularly after his composition book is passed around a classroom.
2016-12-08.headline_main: Review: ‘Slash’ Has Proud Outcasts With Bold Imaginations

2016-12-08.abstract: By 2019, the last one that ties closer Aroldis Chapman to the team, the Yankees envision a competitive roster of matured prospects and star acquisitions.
2016-12-08.snippet: By 2019, the last one that ties closer Aroldis Chapman to the team, the Yankees envision a competitive roster of matured prospects and star acquisitions.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: NATIONAL HARBOR, Md. — You might think a $17.2 million annual salary, a new benchmark for closers, would be enough to get a five-year commitment to the Yankees from Aroldis Chapman. But that is not how free agency works.
2016-12-08.headline_main: Yankees’ Three-Year Plan: Keep Building, Then Collect

2016-12-08.abstract: Everything is an insult, apparently.
2016-12-08.snippet: Everything is an insult, apparently.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: Donald Trump won the electoral college at least in part by promising to bring coal jobs back to Appalachia and manufacturing jobs back to the Rust Belt. Neither promise can be honored – for the most part we’re talking about jobs lost, not to unfair foreign competition, but to technological change. But a funny thing happens when people like me try to point that out: we get enraged responses from economists who feel an affinity for the working people of the afflicted regions – responses that assume that trying to do the numbers must reflect contempt for regional cultures, or something.
2016-12-08.headline_main: The Economics of Regional Self-Esteem

2016-12-08.abstract: Trump supporters hope to wipe away Obama-era environmental regulations. But that may prove difficult to do.
2016-12-08.snippet: Trump supporters hope to wipe away Obama-era environmental regulations. But that may prove difficult to do.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has named Scott Pruitt, a leading opponent of President Obama’s signature environmental initiatives, as his nominee to head the Environmental Protection Agency. Mr. Pruitt, Oklahoma’s attorney general, is closely linked to fossil fuel industries and is a climate change skeptic. He was most likely chosen to reverse these environmental initiatives, a deeply disturbing turn in the nation’s effort to slow climate change.
2016-12-08.headline_main: Dismantling Climate Rules Isn’t So Easy

2016-12-08.abstract: It dropped for the first time since 1993, to 78.8 years.
2016-12-08.snippet: It dropped for the first time since 1993, to 78.8 years.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: American life expectancy is in decline for the first time since 1993, when H.I.V.-related deaths were at their peak. But this time, researchers can’t identify a single problem driving the drop, and are instead pointing to a number of factors, from heart disease to suicides, that have caused a greater number of deaths.
2016-12-08.headline_main: Life Expectancy in U.S. Declines Slightly, and Researchers Are Puzzled

2016-12-08.abstract: Dani Menkin’s documentary recounts this team’s unlikely run to the European Cup championship in 1977, a year in Israel’s history that was more fraught than usual.
2016-12-08.snippet: Dani Menkin’s documentary recounts this team’s unlikely run to the European Cup championship in 1977, a year in Israel’s history that was more fraught than usual.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: How much do you know about the European basketball league? How much do you want to know about the European basketball league? Come on, don’t be provincial. How about the Israeli team in the European basketball league?
2016-12-08.headline_main: Review: The Team That Put Israeli Basketball ‘On the Map’

2016-12-08.abstract: John Noble Wilford tells how, as a New York Times science reporter in July 1969, he wrote the front page article “Men Walk on Moon.” It is the first interview in a new Times series, “I Was There.”

2016-12-08.abstract: Directed by Josh Gordon and Will Speck, this bawdy comedy is full of familiar faces, including Kate McKinnon and Courtney B. Vance, behaving badly.
2016-12-08.snippet: Directed by Josh Gordon and Will Speck, this bawdy comedy is full of familiar faces, including Kate McKinnon and Courtney B. Vance, behaving badly.

2016-12-08.abstract: This adulatory profile focuses on a photojournalist who has documented many high-profile figures, but it skips some hard questions.
2016-12-08.snippet: This adulatory profile focuses on a photojournalist who has documented many high-profile figures, but it skips some hard questions.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: “Harry Benson: Shoot First” is an engaging but too worshipful documentary about Mr. Benson, a photographer who has been taking noteworthy pictures since the early days of the Beatles. The film, by Justin Bare and Matthew Miele, would be better if it spent less time gushing about how great Mr. Benson is and more time confronting some of the questions his approach raises.
2016-12-08.headline_main: Review: ‘Harry Benson: Shoot First,’ on Photographing the Beatles and Others

2016-12-08.snippet: A former assistant to a war journalist resettles in small-town America, where culture clashes turn mysterious and dangerous.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: Dominic Rains is quietly captivating in “Burn Country,” an amorphous study in table-turning directed by Ian Olds, a documentarian who is trying his first feature.
2016-12-08.headline_main: Review: An Afghan in a Strange Land (California) in ‘Burn Country’

2016-12-08.abstract: He had accused the country, a British ally, of “puppeteering” in “proxy wars” across the Middle East and of “abusing Islam,” and he received an upbraiding from Prime Minister Theresa May.
2016-12-08.snippet: He had accused the country, a British ally, of “puppeteering” in “proxy wars” across the Middle East and of “abusing Islam,” and he received an upbraiding from Prime Minister Theresa May.

2016-12-08.abstract: In this horror movie, two brothers play an old-school board game with a videotape and run into Barbara Crampton of “Re-Animator.”
2016-12-08.snippet: In this horror movie, two brothers play an old-school board game with a videotape and run into Barbara Crampton of “Re-Animator.”
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: All hail the VCR: the more or less obsolete technology that keeps on giving. Videotapes and the machines that play them are frequent props in the current crush of nostalgia for the 1980s and ’90s. The latest example is the horror movie “Beyond the Gates,” which shows early promise but eventually ends up in the bin of ordinariness.
2016-12-08.headline_main: Review: A Trip to Hell, via the VCR, in ‘Beyond the Gates’

2016-12-08.abstract: Officials say surviving fighters could go underground and exploit the economic and political vacuum, threatening not only the country but also its neighbors and possibly Europe.
2016-12-08.snippet: Officials say surviving fighters could go underground and exploit the economic and political vacuum, threatening not only the country but also its neighbors and possibly Europe.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Islamic State, though driven from its coastal stronghold in Surt this week, still has several hundred fighters who have dispersed across Libya and pose a threat to the country, its neighbors and, potentially, Europe, according to American officials and the Pentagon’s Africa Command.
2016-12-08.headline_main: ISIS Remains Threat in Libya Despite Defeat in Surt, U.S. Officials Say

2016-12-08.abstract: A palace and a water buffalo calf figure in this Pietro Marcello film — part fable, part documentary — set in the Campania region of Italy.
2016-12-08.snippet: A palace and a water buffalo calf figure in this Pietro Marcello film — part fable, part documentary — set in the Campania region of Italy.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: Part documentary, part beast fable, Pietro Marcello’s “Lost and Beautiful” is a loving act of cultural preservation. It also pays tribute to another such act: the brave and selfless efforts of Tommaso, a shepherd in the southern Italian region of Campania, to protect an 18th-century Bourbon palace from falling into ruin.
2016-12-08.headline_main: Review: Angels, Some of This Earth, in ‘Lost and Beautiful’

2016-12-08.abstract: In Meshell Ndegeocello’s show at Harlem Stage, “The Fire Next Time” might as well be the Bible. And the big question is, “How are you surviving 2016?”
2016-12-08.snippet: In Meshell Ndegeocello’s show at Harlem Stage, “The Fire Next Time” might as well be the Bible. And the big question is, “How are you surviving 2016?”
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: A fierce tide of feeling — rage and despair, love and hope and exaltation — courses through “Can I Get a Witness?,” an almost indefinable work of music theater created by the performer and musician Meshell Ndegeocello, and inspired by “The Fire Next Time,” James Baldwin’s incisive polemic about race in America, first published in 1963.
2016-12-08.headline_main: Review: ‘Can I Get a Witness?’ Takes James Baldwin’s Message to Church

2016-12-08.abstract: In this year’s edition of “New Dances” at the school, Pam Tanowitz’s “thunder rolling along afterward” exhilarated the junior class.
2016-12-08.snippet: In this year’s edition of “New Dances” at the school, Pam Tanowitz’s “thunder rolling along afterward” exhilarated the junior class.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: The first-year students in Juilliard’s dance division already have much of what it takes, on a technical level, to become professional dancers. To be accepted into the program, a dancer has to show immense promise. But to watch the school’s annual “New Dances” concert, featuring new works by four choreographers — one piece per class — is to see how four years of training can build confidence and nuance on top of great technique.
2016-12-08.headline_main: Review: Juilliard Students Try Out a Searing New Dance

2016-12-08.abstract: Frankie and Johnny’s story returns, written and directed by Matthew Ross, but not much has changed except the actors and how well they fit together.
2016-12-08.snippet: Frankie and Johnny’s story returns, written and directed by Matthew Ross, but not much has changed except the actors and how well they fit together.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: Its title is an early tip-off that “Frank & Lola” will be a new riff on Frankie and Johnny’s old troubles. Immortalized in song and onstage, these two have lent their names and heartache to a couple of films. (The movie shares its title with a Jimmy Buffett song.) They’re back in shadow form in “Frank & Lola,” this time with an unpersuasively paired Michael Shannon and Imogen Poots as Las Vegas souls who, after tumbling into bed, fall for each other. Soon, Frank and Lola learn that love still hurts, especially when tendrils of jealously start twisting through the story and he confuses abandon with possession.
2016-12-08.headline_main: Review: ‘Frank & Lola,’ Retreading Old Ground

2016-12-08.abstract: La Ruta de Los Conquistadores, a three-day race across Costa Rica, pits participants against steep climbs, muddy trails and waterways that may or may not contain crocodiles.
2016-12-08.snippet: La Ruta de Los Conquistadores, a three-day race across Costa Rica, pits participants against steep climbs, muddy trails and waterways that may or may not contain crocodiles.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: MATINA, Costa Rica — Just keep moving. Even if only an inch forward. That’s the key.
2016-12-08.headline_main: Conquering River, Jungle and the World’s Toughest Bike Race

2016-12-08.abstract: “Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer: The Musical,” at the Theater at Madison Square Garden, has bucks as well as does, but its message of equality is not fully realized.
2016-12-08.snippet: “Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer: The Musical,” at the Theater at Madison Square Garden, has bucks as well as does, but its message of equality is not fully realized.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: According to “Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer: The Musical,” there’s something even more unheard-of than letting a funny-looking buck play in any reindeer games: allowing a doe to join in.
2016-12-08.headline_main: Review: A ‘Rudolph’ for Inclusion (at Least if You’re a Guy)

2016-12-08.abstract: This loose, loopy and enjoyable seminar on the making of “The Wizard of Oz” combines live video and performance.
2016-12-08.snippet: This loose, loopy and enjoyable seminar on the making of “The Wizard of Oz” combines live video and performance.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: A loose, loopy and enjoyable seminar on the making of “The Wizard of Oz” and its influence on pop culture, this Builders Association production, running through Dec. 18, combines live video and performance. Several famous scenes from the movie are more or less filmed anew before us; the digital video is dazzlingly pristine, and it’s fun to watch the wry comic impersonations of the original performances.. [Read the original review] 800-838-3006, 3ldnyc.org
2016-12-08.headline_main: Review: Beat a New Path Down a Familiar Yellow Brick Road in ‘Elements of Oz’

2016-12-08.abstract: The German artist Hanne Darboven’s magnum opus offers a personal, imperfect vision that absorbs, but never fully clarifies, the 20th century.
2016-12-08.snippet: The German artist Hanne Darboven’s magnum opus offers a personal, imperfect vision that absorbs, but never fully clarifies, the 20th century.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: What force drives societal disaster: too little order, or too much of it? These days of presidential interregnum have seen newspapers’ opinion pages fill with warnings of tyranny and autocracy, fueled by the election of a man whose campaign rhetoric showed disregard for normal rules of conduct. Yet, for many philosophers of the postwar era, too much order seemed just as dangerous as too little. You may dream of perfectly rational government, but fitting the complexities of life into dispassionate systems poses its own hazards. Taken to extremes, as Theodor W. Adorno insisted, the Enlightenment principles of reason and logic would pave the road to Auschwitz.
2016-12-08.headline_main: The Perils of Order, Taken to the Extreme

2016-12-08.abstract: Jaco Van Dormael’s satire follows a bored deity who, from his apartment in Brussels, plays jokes on humans.
2016-12-08.snippet: Jaco Van Dormael’s satire follows a bored deity who, from his apartment in Brussels, plays jokes on humans.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: In the Belgian filmmaker Jaco Van Dormael’s wickedly amusing religious satire, “The Brand New Testament,” God (Benoît Poelvoorde) is a snarling, meanspirited bully who rules the universe from an apartment in Brussels. Inside his locked office, surrounded by walls of card files, the tyrannical, perpetually bored deity sits behind a computer and plays nasty practical jokes on humans. A favorite pastime is contriving Laws of Annoyance, like making sure that when a piece of toast falls, it always lands with the jelly side down.
2016-12-08.headline_main: Review: God Is Alive and Crabby, According to ‘The Brand New Testament’

2016-12-08.abstract: A teenage girl and her downtrodden mother struggle to build a normal life, but any progress they make seems to unravel.
2016-12-08.snippet: A teenage girl and her downtrodden mother struggle to build a normal life, but any progress they make seems to unravel.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: Homelessness, alcoholism, real estate chicanery, the financial crisis, teenage drug abuse and transgender discrimination: These are some of the themes dutifully trotted out and glossed over in the screen adaptation of Annie Weatherwax’s 2014 novel, “All We Had.” Although sensitively handled in the film, it all adds up to an overload of baggage for a well-meaning but formulaic movie with not enough time to transcend predictable clichés.
2016-12-08.headline_main: Review: Katie Holmes Directs Her First Feature, ‘All We Had’

2016-12-08.abstract: This is MoMA’s first show that traces the progress of one art movement, assembled entirely from the museum’s collection.
2016-12-08.snippet: This is MoMA’s first show that traces the progress of one art movement, assembled entirely from the museum’s collection.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: The Museum of Modern Art more or less set the standard for the broad swath of media typically collected by a fine-art museum by creating the first departments of photography, film, architecture and design. But then a weird primness set in: Departmental holdings were rarely allowed to mix in the galleries. The divisions remained intact even as the hybrid forms of 1970s art sowed confusion. (Performance art, video, Conceptual Art, anyone?) Then, to the dismay of many, the system was once more reinforced by the museum’s 2004 redesign, which gave all departments their own dedicated galleries.
2016-12-08.headline_main: The Russian Avant-Garde Rising in ‘A Revolutionary Impulse’

2016-12-08.abstract: A woman in Delhi whose brain has been annexed by worry craves an escape.
2016-12-08.snippet: A woman in Delhi whose brain has been annexed by worry craves an escape.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: The brain is capable of remarkable flimflam. We act on impulse, and only later start looking for a logical justification for it; we somehow find ways to intellectually defend what’s in our gut. As the psychologist Jonathan Haidt likes to say, we rely on an inner lawyer, not an inner scientist, to do our moral reasoning.
2016-12-08.headline_main: Review: In ‘The Private Life of Mrs. Sharma,’ a Search for Release

2016-12-08.abstract: If you trace most food chains back far enough, you get sunlight. But trace back that of the Caribbean spiny lobster, and you get swamp gas.
2016-12-08.snippet: If you trace most food chains back far enough, you get sunlight. But trace back that of the Caribbean spiny lobster, and you get swamp gas.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: If you’ve ever ordered a lobster tail from Red Lobster, there’s a good chance some of your meal can be traced back to swamp gas.
2016-12-08.headline_main: The Freaky Food Chain Behind Your Lobster Dinner

2016-12-08.abstract: The reporter Ellen Barry follows up on a young woman who was the subject of her report about efforts in India to place poor young rural women in urban manufacturing jobs.
2016-12-08.snippet: The reporter Ellen Barry follows up on a young woman who was the subject of her report about efforts in India to place poor young rural women in urban manufacturing jobs.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: Times Insider provides behind-the-scenes insights from The New York Times. In this piece, The Times’s South Asia Bureau Chief, Ellen Barry, follows up on a report she wrote earlier this fall about efforts in India to place poor young rural women in minimum-wage manufacturing jobs.
2016-12-08.headline_main: Follow-Up: A New Ending in Tale of Young Woman From Rural India

2016-12-08.snippet: The collection at the Metropolitan Museum of Art holds a number of remarkable depictions of powerful women. Here’s our 50-minute critic’s guide.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: New Yorkers live booked-up lives, and tourists are the busiest people in town. Who else dashes in beat-the-clock time from the World Trade Center to Rockefeller Center, to Trump Tower to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, pausing for selfies at each stop?
2016-12-08.headline_main: Got an Hour? See the Met These 4 Ways

2016-12-08.abstract: Galas were held for the Committee to Protect Journalists, Berggruen Institute, Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, and Food Allergy Research and Education.
2016-12-08.snippet: Galas were held for the Committee to Protect Journalists, Berggruen Institute, Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, and Food Allergy Research and Education.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: The 19th annual Food Allergy Ball, which benefits Food Allergy Research and Education, was Dec. 5 at the Waldorf Astoria. The Berggruen Institute, a philosophical think tank based in Los Angeles, awarded the inaugural Berggruen Prize on Dec. 1 to the Canadian philosopher Charles Taylor at the New York Public Library; the $1 million award recognizes a living thinker of great influence. The Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory honored Alan Alda and P. Roy Vaglos at its Double Helix Medals ceremony Dec. 1 at the American Museum of Natural History. And the Committee to Protect Journalists held its International Press Freedom Awards on Nov. 22 at the Waldorf Astoria.
2016-12-08.headline_main: Thinkers and Scientists

2016-12-08.abstract: In a traveling trunk, a daughter discovered her mother’s lost literary legacy. Now, nearly 30 years after Ms. Collins’s death, a collection has been published.
2016-12-08.snippet: In a traveling trunk, a daughter discovered her mother’s lost literary legacy. Now, nearly 30 years after Ms. Collins’s death, a collection has been published.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: When Nina Collins was 19 and studying in Europe, she had a distressing phone conversation with her mother. I have cancer, and you need to come home, her mother said, but don’t worry, I’m going to be fine.
2016-12-08.headline_main: Kathleen Collins’s Short Stories Were Almost Lost to History

2016-12-08.abstract: Suggested reading by book critics and editors at The New York Times.
2016-12-08.snippet: Suggested reading by book critics and editors at The New York Times.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: The holidays are upon us, and it’s time to think about books for the giving and books we’d love to receive ourselves. Our list this week is heavy — but lighthearted too! — on books about the visual and performance arts. Among them are works that put us in a celebratory mood, or at least get our minds off more mundane and/or troubling matters.
2016-12-08.headline_main: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week

2016-12-08.abstract: They refused to vote on a draft of a 10-year plan for spending on major projects like a replacement for the bus terminal in Midtown Manhattan.

2016-12-08.headline_main: Governors Compromise on Port Authority Plan. Commissioners Don’t Go Along.

2016-12-08.abstract: John Glenn, a symbol of the space age as the first American to orbit Earth, sat down with John Schwartz in 2012 — the 50th anniversary of his flight — to talk about making history and that “beautiful view.”

2016-12-08.abstract: Congestion in Midtown will seem like a board-game problem if fears about drastic federal cuts are borne out, at a time when New York faces a growing homelessness crisis.
2016-12-08.snippet: Congestion in Midtown will seem like a board-game problem if fears about drastic federal cuts are borne out, at a time when New York faces a growing homelessness crisis.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: For the last several weeks, discussions of the ways a Trump presidency will affect life in New York City have revolved largely around questions of inconvenience, when they might have been better cast as questions of sustainability. Congestion in Midtown will seem like a board-game problem if fears about drastic federal cuts to social services are borne out, at a time when New York, like other major cities, faces a growing homelessness crisis. Conveniently, Donald J. Trump’s naming of Ben Carson as his choice to run the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development provides us with a vehicle in which we might drive closer to some of the more darkly imagined consequences.
2016-12-08.headline_main: With Trump, Fear the Social Service Cuts, Not the Traffic

2016-12-08.abstract: A reader asks about a park-within-a-park near the Korean War Memorial in Battery Park.
2016-12-08.snippet: A reader asks about a park-within-a-park near the Korean War Memorial in Battery Park.
2016-12-08.lead_paragraph: Q. Before Hurricane Sandy, a lovely, messy little circular park-within-a-park near the Korean War Memorial in Battery Park had a sign that labeled it Walloon Park. That area reopened just last year and is now labeled Jerusalem Cove. It features a vegetable and flower garden as well as the cedars and the circular labyrinth that were there before (though the cedars are half-dead, poor things, from hurricane damage). What happened to the name Walloon Park?
2016-12-08.headline_main: What Happened to Walloon Park?

2016-12-09.abstract: About 535 million children worldwide now live in countries destabilized by conflicts and calamities, Unicef announced.
2016-12-09.snippet: About 535 million children worldwide now live in countries destabilized by conflicts and calamities, Unicef announced.
2016-12-09.lead_paragraph: More than a half-billion children, or roughly one in four, now live in countries affected by conflicts or other disasters, the United Nations Children’s Fund said Thursday.
2016-12-09.headline_main: U.N. Says Nearly One in Four Children Live in Conflict or Disaster Zones

2016-12-09.snippet: Donald J. Trump’s stance on climate change has ignited a debate over a plan by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau to reduce carbon emissions by putting a price on them.

2016-12-09.lead_paragraph: Even Manhattan’s hard edges soften at holiday time. Twinkle lights outglow fluorescents; sturdy woolen pompom hats replace flimsy knit beanies; marshmallow-speckled hot chocolate competes with black coffee.

2016-12-09.snippet: To the photographer Neal Slavin, it is surprising how much humanity is revealed in a group portrait.
2016-12-09.lead_paragraph: Neal Slavin took his first group portrait in 1972, photographing members of the Flushing Volunteer Ambulance Corps, along with trophies they had won for ambulance racing and other acts of derring-do.
