2016-12-20.abstract: Los Angeles’s strip malls have long been strongholds of splendid traditional ethnic restaurants. Now they are home to ultracreative ones, helmed by daring new chefs.
2016-12-20.snippet: Los Angeles’s strip malls have long been strongholds of splendid traditional ethnic restaurants. Now they are home to ultracreative ones, helmed by daring new chefs.
2016-12-20.lead_paragraph: I lived in, and loved, Los Angeles for about nine years, so I can get away with saying this: Very little is more Los Angeles than a strip mall. These asphalt-dominated bastions of cheapness and parking sum up so much about what I love and hate about the city. They’re ugly and kitschy, yet they leave room for weird, unexpected, often wonderful surprises, hidden right under your nose.
2016-12-20.headline_main: 6 Standout Restaurants in Los Angeles Strip Malls

2016-12-20.lead_paragraph: The director Peter Berg and the actor Mark Wahlberg have collaborated on three films dramatizing real-life calamities in the past four years. Their first, “Lone Survivor” from 2013, chronicled an unsuccessful 2005 Navy SEAL mission to kill a Taliban leader in Afghanistan. This year’s “Deepwater Horizon” was about a fatal 2010 disaster involving an oil rig collapse off the Louisiana coast. Now comes “Patriots Day,” about the Boston Marathon bombing of April 15, 2013.
2016-12-20.headline_main: Review: ‘Patriots Day,’ a Mosaic of Portraits From Marathon Bombing

2016-12-20.abstract: Would my mixed-race son feel that he was represented by a black Santa or a white one?
2016-12-20.snippet: Would my mixed-race son feel that he was represented by a black Santa or a white one?
2016-12-20.lead_paragraph: When my friend posted an adorable picture of her son with a black Santa in New York City, I was drawn to the idea of visiting a Santa who reflected my family’s skin tones. I’m black, and my 3-year-old son’s father is white. I am raising him as a single mom with the help of my parents. Why should white Santa be the default?
2016-12-20.headline_main: Seeing Santa in Black and White

2016-12-20.snippet: Using a novel constitutional argument, advocates made a final plea to President Obama to shield up to 200,000 legal immigrants with minor criminal records from deportation.
2016-12-20.lead_paragraph: ALAMANCE COUNTY, N.C. — Confronting a tight deadline and armed with a creative legal argument, immigration advocates have made a final plea to President Obama to shield up to 200,000 legal immigrants with minor criminal records from deportation.

2016-12-20.abstract: This time of year, Newgrange takes on a special significance when the Irish Neolithic site mysteriously aligns with the rising sun at winter solstice.
2016-12-20.snippet: This time of year, Newgrange takes on a special significance when the Irish Neolithic site mysteriously aligns with the rising sun at winter solstice.
2016-12-20.lead_paragraph: About a half-mile past the entrance to Newgrange, in the Valley of the Boyne, County Meath, Ireland, is a handmade sign with an arrow that reads “Irish crafts for sale.” I am, of course, fascinated by Newgrange, a Neolithic site that predates Stonehenge by a thousand years, but I can never pass up yarn, so I turned into a modest farm, damp, green, full of sheep, well-used equipment and warning signs — “This is not a playground.”
2016-12-20.headline_main: Jane Smiley Explores Ancient Ireland’s Mysterious Tombs

2016-12-20.abstract: Lynne Elworthy has been dismissed after speaking up, in defiance of gag orders, to denounce the cruelty of Australia’s refugee policy.
2016-12-20.snippet: Lynne Elworthy has been dismissed after speaking up, in defiance of gag orders, to denounce the cruelty of Australia’s refugee policy.
2016-12-20.lead_paragraph: From the start of its “offshore processing” program that has seen more than 2,000 asylum seekers and refugees dumped on two remote Pacific islands, Australia has relied on draconian nondisclosure contracts to keep the extent of its brutality secret. But this month Lynne Elworthy, an Australian mental health nurse employed on Manus Island in Papua New Guinea, defied the gag clauses and a federal law against whistle-blowers to tell me the policy was an exercise in “absolute cruelty.”
2016-12-20.headline_main: Australia’s Brave Whistleblower Nurse

2016-12-20.abstract: Frequent hotel guests should tip double, and everyone should tip more on the actual holiday.
2016-12-20.snippet: Frequent hotel guests should tip double, and everyone should tip more on the actual holiday.
2016-12-20.lead_paragraph: Even frequent travelers scratch their heads when it comes to how much they should tip hotel employees, tour guides and others who provide services when they are on the road. The holiday season, however, adds another element of confusion to a practice that is already perplexing enough: Are you supposed to give an extra tip in the spirit of the season to the concierge at your hotel who helps with dinner reservations or the Uber driver taking you to the airport? What about the travel agent you use to book your vacations?
2016-12-20.headline_main: How Travelers Should Tip During the Holidays (and How Much)

2016-12-20.lead_paragraph: “What will people think?” That’s a question that has luckily never concerned me. A case in point. 1976. Northwestern University. The theater department wasn’t quite ready for me. I was too light (euphemism for gay), too thin and just too … too much.

2016-12-20.abstract: The children’s books authors R.J. Palacio and Meg Medina talk to Maria Russo, The Times’ children’s books editor, about being — and choosing not to be — a Latina author.
2016-12-20.snippet: The children’s books authors R.J. Palacio and Meg Medina talk to Maria Russo, The Times’ children’s books editor, about being — and choosing not to be — a Latina author.
2016-12-20.lead_paragraph: R.J. Palacio and Meg Medina both grew up in Spanish-speaking households. As elementary-school students at P.S. 22 in Flushing, Queens, they were best friends. Medina moved away at 11, and they lost touch. Years later they discovered they had both grown up to become children’s book authors. Both have achieved renown: Palacio (whose real name is Raquel Jaramillo) wrote “Wonder,” the best-selling middle-grade novel many credit with launching a worldwide movement to teach kids to choose kindness. Medina has written several award-winning books for all age groups, most recently the young adult novel “Burn Baby Burn,” longlisted for the 2016 National Book Award and shortlisted for the Kirkus Prize. When they reconnected, Palacio and Medina found they still had much in common. But in one way they have taken different paths: Medina identifies as a Latina writer, writes about Latino characters, and speaks often about diversity issues. Palacio does not.
2016-12-20.headline_main: R.J. Palacio and Meg Medina Talk Diversity and Children’s Books

2016-12-20.abstract: Bill Belisle has coached at Mount St. Charles Academy in Woonsocket, R.I., since 1975. But when this season opened, it was “just like my first game.”
2016-12-20.snippet: Bill Belisle has coached at Mount St. Charles Academy in Woonsocket, R.I., since 1975. But when this season opened, it was “just like my first game.”
2016-12-20.lead_paragraph: WOONSOCKET, R.I. — Around 6:15 p.m. on Dec. 2, Bill Belisle boarded a bus in front of Adelard Arena, just as he had done hundreds of times before. That night, Belisle and the rest of the Mount St. Charles Academy high school hockey team traveled 20 miles south for their season opener in Cranston. Belisle, 87, couldn’t wait to begin his 42nd season as Mount’s head coach.
2016-12-20.headline_main: After 42 Seasons and 32 Titles, a Hockey Coach Can’t Wait for the Next Game

2016-12-20.snippet: The ride-hailing service has racked up impressive growth, and it has claimed a big share of the market. That could mean capturing more customers might be harder.
2016-12-20.lead_paragraph: Uber Technologies could encounter a bumpy ride into public markets. The ride-hailing service has spent the last several years racking up impressive growth. It also has raised easily at least $15 billion, in the process inflating its value to about $68 billion on paper. That will make the next round, possibly in a 2017 initial public offering, tougher.
2016-12-20.headline_main: Uber Aims to Be More Than a People Mover

2016-12-20.abstract: Filtered Coffee opens a new branch in Washington Heights, and other restaurant news.
2016-12-20.snippet: Filtered Coffee opens a new branch in Washington Heights, and other restaurant news.
2016-12-20.lead_paragraph: PRETTY SOUTHERN The chef Sam Talbot, most recently based in Maine, grew up near Charleston, S.C., so he’s particular about his fried chicken. He has also been a private chef for professional basketball players and racecar drivers, and said that many of them wanted tempting food like fried chicken and biscuits to be gluten-free. That’s what has inspired his new casual venture into Southern fare. “It can be healthy,” he said. The fried chicken and biscuits are available with or without gluten, as are the mac and cheese, potpies, several sandwiches and some of the desserts. He makes his own gluten-free flour, and cooks his grits in coconut milk, to accommodate dairy-free diets. The dozen or so sides are based mostly on organic vegetables, and there are also rotisserie chickens. The restaurant will be in a small space with exposed brick, a sleek bar and 22 seats indoors, 20 outside. (Opens Thursday): 14 Bedford Avenue (Lorimer Street), Greenpoint, Brooklyn, 718-349-2967, prettysouthernbk.com.
2016-12-20.headline_main: Pretty Southern, Serving Gluten-Free Comfort Foods, to Open in Greenpoint

2016-12-20.lead_paragraph: Unheralded and unhyped, “The Autopsy of Jane Doe” sneaks into theaters like a chilly treat among the Christmas comedies and Force-fed mythologizing. The first solo English-language feature from the Norwegian director André Ovredal — an infinitely more disciplined follow-up to his 2011 film, “Trollhunter” — this shivery tour through a young woman’s innards turns putrefaction into a puzzle.

2016-12-20.lead_paragraph: The things you can do with computer animation these days are just more and more amazing. In “Sing,” a funny animal jukebox musical cartoon written and directed by Garth Jennings (“Son of Rambow”), there is a scene in which two postpunk porcupines, one of whom has been selected to compete in a vocal competition, argue at home about the state of their relationship, and their musical direction. During their quarrel I thought, with absolute earnestness, “Wow, these porcupines have an unusually spacious apartment.”
2016-12-20.headline_main: Review: ‘Sing’ Gives Animated Belters a Stage

2016-12-20.abstract: Jennifer Lawrence stars in this interplanetary romance aboard a mechanically doomed spacecraft making a 120-year voyage.
2016-12-20.snippet: Jennifer Lawrence stars in this interplanetary romance aboard a mechanically doomed spacecraft making a 120-year voyage.
2016-12-20.lead_paragraph: There is a blazing light at the center of the interplanetary romance “Passengers,” and its name is Jennifer Lawrence. In a love story whose attempt to be an interstellar “Titanic” eventually falls flat, Ms. Lawrence’s character, Aurora, is an ambitious journalist aboard the Avalon, a commercial spacecraft making a historic 120-year voyage. Its destination is Homestead II, a pioneer colony of an overcrowded Earth. The spunky, whip-smart Aurora, who bought a round-trip ticket, hopes to write the first book about Homestead II upon her return to New York.
2016-12-20.headline_main: Review: Two ‘Passengers’ Trapped on a Spaceship Find Love Amid Despair

2016-12-20.abstract: Pedro Almodóvar’s heroine in his new movie about loss is drawn from the stories of Alice Munro; both artists are attuned to the inner lives of women.
2016-12-20.snippet: Pedro Almodóvar’s heroine in his new movie about loss is drawn from the stories of Alice Munro; both artists are attuned to the inner lives of women.
2016-12-20.lead_paragraph: According to a poem by Elizabeth Bishop, “the art of losing isn’t hard to master.” But making a masterwork on the subject of loss, a perennial theme in art, may be harder than it looks. The young adulthood and middle age of Julieta, the heroine of Pedro Almodóvar’s new movie, are shadowed by death and abandonment, which she does her best to handle gracefully. Mr. Almodóvar, for his part, tells her story with his characteristic later-period blend of elegant restraint and keening melodrama. “Julieta” is scrupulous, compassionate and surprising, even if it does not always quite communicate the full gravity and sweep of the feelings it engages.
2016-12-20.headline_main: Review: Another Woman on the Verge in Almodóvar’s ‘Julieta’

2016-12-20.abstract: In her frisky, adventurous new biography, Julia Baird said she was determined “to hack through myths, not hew to them.”
2016-12-20.snippet: In her frisky, adventurous new biography, Julia Baird said she was determined “to hack through myths, not hew to them.”
2016-12-20.lead_paragraph: You can learn a lot about a queen from the contents of her coffin. In her frisky, adventurous new biography of Queen Victoria, Julia Baird offers not only an inventory of the items with which the queen wished to be buried but also the exact placement she specified for them. Of course her treasured husband, Prince Albert, would be represented; Victoria had spent much of her life draped in black, showily mourning his death. So Albert’s framed photograph and a cast of his hand were duly buried with her.
2016-12-20.headline_main: Review: ‘Victoria the Queen’ Delves Into Her Epic Reign

2016-12-20.lead_paragraph: “Play with the feet!” Karina Elver called out to a group of dancers running through the tricky pas de six from “Napoli,” an 1842 ballet by the Danish choreographer August Bournonville. “Stop!” she cried before offering a little lecture. “This is not the Russian style, no showing off!” she said. “Remember for Bournonville, you are always very calm. Remember you are sweethearts together, very loving.”

2016-12-21.lead_paragraph: The populist right has wasted no time waiting for facts to emerge about the identity of the attacker in Berlin or a motive to slam Chancellor Angela Merkel for her humane asylum policy and to push its xenophobic agenda. This dangerous — if predictable — reaction plays directly into the hands of the Islamic State, which would like nothing better than to start a war between Christians and Muslims in Europe.

It seemed silly, not a big deal. “Someone forgot to turn a switch, I thought,” Mr. Hewitt said this week. “An anomaly.”

2016-12-21.abstract: To make a good puzzle, you need a good idea. Jeff Chen and Seth Geltman show us an example.
2016-12-21.snippet: To make a good puzzle, you need a good idea. Jeff Chen and Seth Geltman show us an example.
2016-12-21.lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — As part of my college major in Strategic Guessing, also known to some as marketing, I took an advertising class where an ad’s Big Idea was as elusive as the Holy Grail. The professor’s methods were probably not the best way to go about encouraging creativity, but I can remember him systematically shooting down any idea for a class campaign that he did not believe was a Big Idea. That, in a nutshell, is probably why the vast majority of my graduating class became accountants.
2016-12-21.headline_main: Shoot for the Moon

The only things missing are the monks.
2016-12-21.headline_main: A Maestro for the Masses, if Not the Critics

2016-12-21.abstract: A diverse array of restaurants, bars and stores have opened in Gowanus, where a namesake toxic canal and desolate vibe once kept people away.
2016-12-21.snippet: A diverse array of restaurants, bars and stores have opened in Gowanus, where a namesake toxic canal and desolate vibe once kept people away.
2016-12-21.lead_paragraph: Gowanus, a Brooklyn neighborhood tucked between Park Slope and Carroll Gardens, has shed its must-avoid reputation. Its namesake toxic canal and desolate feel used to keep people away, but in recent years, efforts by groups to clean up the canal and build green spaces along the water have led to a renaissance. New eye-catching apartment buildings dot the skyline, and a diverse array of restaurants, bars and stores have opened, bringing fresh life to a gritty area once known more for its auto repair shops than its attractive spots. Now the sidewalks have foot traffic, and optimism is in the air.
2016-12-21.headline_main: Five Places to Go in Gowanus, Brooklyn

And Lin-Manuel Miranda, Michael Phelps and some other game changers reminisce about their very good years.

2016-12-21.snippet: Peter Loehr, chief of Legendary East, discusses the making of the $150 million co-production, the biggest so far, and criticism over the casting of its star, Matt Damon.
2016-12-21.lead_paragraph: The continuing courtship between Hollywood and China reached a new milestone last Friday with the release in China of “The Great Wall,” the much buzzed-about movie directed by Zhang Yimou and backed by Legendary Entertainment, Universal Pictures, Le Vision Pictures and China Film Group. With a budget of more than $150 million, the blockbuster epic, which features Matt Damon and Andy Lau fighting monsters on the iconic Great Wall, is the biggest co-production to date for the United States and China and probably the most expensive movie ever shot exclusively in China.
2016-12-21.headline_main: ‘Great Wall’ Producer on What Hollywood and China Can Teach Each Other

2016-12-21.lead_paragraph: SOFIA, Bulgaria — Being Bulgarian, I can tell you that international news media cover elections in small European countries the same way a literature professor reads a spy novel during a summer holiday: It’s a pleasant diversion, but one quickly forgets the characters, and it doesn’t really matter if the narrative gets scrambled. Normally, this is not a problem, but it can become one next year.

2016-12-21.lead_paragraph: The Donald Trump presidency is not yet officially upon us, but the Trump era has already been good for political reading lists. Book buyers baffled by Trumpism and seeking understanding have turned to various sociologies of the ur-Trump voter, making best sellers out of J. D. Vance’s “Hillbilly Elegy,” Nancy Isenberg’s “White Trash” and Arlie Russell Hochschild’s “Strangers in Their Own Land.”

And it could have an even more immediate and direct impact on economic growth: student debt relief.

2016-12-21.lead_paragraph: New York — Guess which country has recently shown the greatest willingness to weather hardship in order to pay its foreign bondholders? Paradoxically, it’s the country that has been among the most vocal in its anticapitalist rhetoric. Venezuela continues to pay despite an economic crisis that would have stymied other sovereign borrowers long ago. Riots prompted by a shortage of cash are just the latest example of the country’s economic crisis. Although reallocating funds from debt service to the importation of much-needed food and medicine is tempting, the government fears that subsequent lawsuits could actually leave less money for imports.
2016-12-21.headline_main: Why Venezuela Should Default

2016-12-21.snippet: Declines have been driven by rulings limiting the use of the death penalty, moratoriums, the cost of appeals and difficulty obtaining lethal injection drugs, a research group said.
2016-12-21.lead_paragraph: Executions, new death sentences and public support for capital punishment in the United States all fell this year to their lowest levels in decades, continuing sharp declines underway since the 1990s. States carried out fewer executions in 2016 than they had in 25 years, and juries imposed fewer death sentences than in any year since 1972, when the Supreme Court struck down all of the death penalty laws then on the books.
2016-12-21.headline_main: Executions Hit 25-Year Low and Support Is Falling, Report Finds

2016-12-21.abstract: The Queens collective the Juice Crew is getting back together for reunion shows in Manhattan and Montclair, N.J.
2016-12-21.snippet: The Queens collective the Juice Crew is getting back together for reunion shows in Manhattan and Montclair, N.J.
2016-12-21.lead_paragraph: By New York standards, the New Year’s Eve options are thin, so get your fix earlier in the week with a rap-history field trip: a reunion of the Juice Crew, the Queens collective responsible for so much essential music in the mid-to-late 1980s. Anchored by the producer Marley Marl, it included a wide range of provocative rappers. Big Daddy Kane was mercilessly smooth, Kool G Rap a rough-edged storyteller. Craig G was wildly improvisational, and MC Shan and Masta Ace were hard boasters. In Roxanne Shanté, they had one of rap’s foundational tough women, and in Biz Markie, one of rap’s foundational comedians. Individually, their careers took wildly different directions, but their collective legacy remains strong. These reunion shows, on Thursday, Dec. 29, and Friday, will provide a rare opportunity to see “The Symphony,” the 1988 Juice Crew posse cut that set a high-water mark for the form, performed live and in full. (Thursday, B. B. King Blues Club & Grill, bbkingblues.com; Friday, Wellmont Theater, Montclair, N.J., wellmonttheater.com.)
2016-12-21.headline_main: The Juice Crew: A Rap History Reunion

2016-12-21.abstract: Noche Flamenca returns with a five-week season at the West-Park Presbyterian Church.
2016-12-21.snippet: Noche Flamenca returns with a five-week season at the West-Park Presbyterian Church.
2016-12-21.lead_paragraph: The remarkable Noche Flamenca enlists the typical elements of flamenco music and dance — pathos and passion, catharsis and tension — yet part of what makes this company so absorbing is its intimacy. Formed in 1993 by a husband-and-wife team, the director Martín Santangelo and the dancer Soledad Barrio, Noche Flamenca returns with a five-week season at the West-Park Presbyterian Church that features its acclaimed dance-drama “Antigona,” an adaptation of Sophocles’ “Antigone” starring the fiery Ms. Barrio. It’s a part she was born to play.
2016-12-21.headline_main: Flamenco With a Difference: Hip-Hop and Antigone, Too

2016-12-21.abstract: Alan Gilbert conducts the New York Philharmonic and the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra in the world premiere of Mr. Marsalis’s “The Jungle.”
2016-12-21.snippet: Alan Gilbert conducts the New York Philharmonic and the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra in the world premiere of Mr. Marsalis’s “The Jungle.”
2016-12-21.lead_paragraph: Though the week after Christmas is usually a slow period for classical music, the New York Philharmonic has a worthy program. On Wednesday, Dec. 28, Alan Gilbert conducts the combined forces of the Philharmonic and the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra in the world premiere of Wynton Marsalis’s “The Jungle” (Symphony No. 4), a Philharmonic commission. The concert also offers William Bolcom’s Trombone Concerto, a lively, inventive piece that Mr. Gilbert and the orchestra introduced in June; it’s written for Joseph Alessi, the orchestra’s principal trombone, who is again the soloist. The program opens with Copland’s “Quiet City.” (7:30 p.m. Wednesday and Thursday, 8 p.m. Friday, and 7:30 p.m. on Jan. 3; David Geffen Hall, nyphil.org.)
2016-12-21.headline_main: A New Work From Wynton Marsalis at David Geffen Hall

2016-12-21.lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — A behind-the-scenes look at the coming comedy “Why Him?” is available on YouTube. The video features a lot of hugging, the smiling faces of the stars Bryan Cranston, James Franco and Keegan-Michael Key, and, often, a happy, playful vibe. When asked if the on-set atmosphere of “Why Him?” ever turned circuslike, Mr. Key, sitting alongside Mr. Franco and Mr. Cranston, paused for a second. “A circus?” he said in a thoughtful, measured tone. “Hmmm. Yes, that’s about right.”
2016-12-21.headline_main: Talking ‘Why Him?’ With Bryan Cranston, James Franco and Keegan-Michael Key

2016-12-21.abstract: A show at the Oakland Museum of California looks at the ubiquitous footwear through time.
2016-12-21.snippet: A show at the Oakland Museum of California looks at the ubiquitous footwear through time.
2016-12-21.lead_paragraph: The complex life of the world’s most ubiquitous footwear may flash before the eyes in “Out of the Box: The Rise of Sneaker Culture” at the Oakland Museum of California. Organized by the estimable Bata Shoe Museum of Toronto with the American Federation of Arts in New York, the exhibition promises nearly 150 examples of this indispensable item. Some date to the first half of the 19th century and the onset of pre-vulcanized rubber overshoes. From there, the show traces the sneaker’s ascent; its role in sports, hip-hop and men’s style; and its evolving technology and breakthroughs.
2016-12-21.headline_main: ‘Out of the Box’ Explores the Rise of the Sneaker

2016-12-21.lead_paragraph: The Metrograph — the more-than-welcome downtown repertory cinema, complete with a bookstore and restaurant, and home to inventive film series — scores again with “From Coraline to Kubo: The Magic of Laika,” a tribute to the growing Hillsboro, Ore., animation studio. Creatively, Laika has challenged Pixar and DreamWorks Animation with its skilled blending of digital imagery and stop-motion, evident in films like “ParaNorman,” “The Boxtrolls” and, this year, “Kubo and the Two Strings,” which the program offers in 3-D.

2016-12-21.lead_paragraph: On Facebook recently, the gifted cabaret singer Liz Callaway posted that she was going to see “Fiddler on the Roof” for the very first time. Friends chimed in, with some registering surprise. (She posted the next day that she adored it.) We all — even critics — have a surprising gap or two in our theatergoing histories. But if you, like Ms. Callaway, are still a “Fiddler” virgin, you have but a week to see the exquisite Broadway revival of this classic musical, directed by Bartlett Sher, which closes on New Year’s Eve.
2016-12-21.headline_main: ‘Fiddler on the Roof’ Revival Has Its Final Notes

2016-12-21.lead_paragraph: J. A. Bayona has made a specialty of slyly inserting family dramas into genre films. This Spanish filmmaker spun a creepy horror movie with a family drama at its center for his first feature, “The Orphanage.” And he staged a destructive tsunami that pulls a family apart (and together) in the thriller “The Impossible.” In “A Monster Calls,” in theaters Friday, Dec. 23, he returns to family drama again, this time mixing in fantasy to tell the story of how the 12-year-old Conor copes with his mother’s terminal illness when he is visited by a treelike monster.

2016-12-21.lead_paragraph: Early on Oct. 6, Erin Piche-Pitts was awakened by the sound of her baby crying. She later told the authorities in Florida that she had picked him up from a bassinet, prepared some formula in a bottle and settled back into bed with him, propping him up with a pillow and nestling his head in the crook of her arm. Then she dozed off.

Finally, unsuccessfully fighting back tears, he turned toward the host’s desk and told him, “I love you.”

2016-12-21.lead_paragraph: No, the Off Broadway musical “Ride the Cyclone,” which follows a group of teenagers who meet a deadly fate on an amusement park roller coaster, isn’t a riff on the movie “Final Destination 3,” where characters meet a similar end. And no, the plot — which has the kids singing in a kind of purgatory — wasn’t inspired by the musical “Forever Plaid,” where a quartet performs a concert from the afterlife after being killed in an accident. Nor by “Cats,” with which it shares some narrative threads.
2016-12-21.headline_main: Bowie and a Flooded Amusement Park: What Inspired ‘Ride the Cyclone’

2016-12-21.snippet: America must expand its clean-energy plans to make room for new, safer reactors.
2016-12-21.lead_paragraph: If 20 fire marshals came around and told us our houses were about to burn down, we’d buy some fire insurance. So when the leading science academies in 20 developed countries, along with several major American corporations and the national security community, all tell us that burning fossil fuels is causing dangerous changes to the climate, we think it’s time for the United States to get serious about clean energy. It also means supporting safely operating nuclear power plants that produce carbon-free electricity.

2016-12-21.abstract: Two new books, “No Sleep: NYC Nightlife Flyers 1988-1999” and “No Half Steppin’,” take a look at clubs in the 1980s and ’90s.
2016-12-21.snippet: Two new books, “No Sleep: NYC Nightlife Flyers 1988-1999” and “No Half Steppin’,” take a look at clubs in the 1980s and ’90s.
2016-12-21.lead_paragraph: The most valuable and also vexing thing about nightclubs is that you can’t get in. Not to the good ones, at least. Not unless you are in the know, or in good standing with people who are, or are diligent and passionate and perhaps willing to part with a bit of cash. Nightclubs are not for public consumption — there is a clear demarcation line of knowledge and access, and the mythology of a great club is built as much by the curious kept on the outside as the revelers doing damage on the inside.
2016-12-21.headline_main: When New York’s Nightclubs Were Secret Empires

2016-12-22.abstract: A dire warning should frighten all democratic nations in which populist rulers have taken or threaten to take power.
2016-12-22.snippet: A dire warning should frighten all democratic nations in which populist rulers have taken or threaten to take power.
2016-12-22.lead_paragraph: The dire warning issued by the departing president of Poland’s highest constitutional court was one that should frighten not only the Poles, but people of all democratic nations in which populist rulers have taken or threaten to take power. Andrzej Rzeplinski, whose term expired on Monday, said that the governing Law and Justice Party is systematically weakening the checks and balances provided by the courts, the press and other institutions, and is leading the country “on the road to autocracy.”

2016-12-22.lead_paragraph: After attacking Boeing and Lockheed Martin on Twitter over the costs of military contracts, President-elect Donald J. Trump met Wednesday with the chief executives of the two aerospace companies, saying his goal was to try to “bring costs down.”

2016-12-22.abstract: A panel created to investigate the deadly Sept. 19 assault on a humanitarian aid convoy in northern Syria said bombs from aircraft were responsible.
2016-12-22.snippet: A panel created to investigate the deadly Sept. 19 assault on a humanitarian aid convoy in northern Syria said bombs from aircraft were responsible.

This was three seasons ago, when Burgdoerfer played defense for the Condors and the team was off to a 1-10-0-1 start.
2016-12-22.headline_main: A Call-Up’s Story: Years in the Minors, Four Days in the N.H.L.

2016-12-22.abstract: Islamist terrorists just bombed a church in a horrific attack, but all too often Copts are the victims of ordinary mob violence.
2016-12-22.snippet: Islamist terrorists just bombed a church in a horrific attack, but all too often Copts are the victims of ordinary mob violence.
2016-12-22.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The Dec. 11 bombing of a church in the Cairo cathedral complex — the seat of the Coptic pope — has been claimed by the Islamic State, although the Egyptian government has blamed the Muslim Brotherhood. Whoever planted the bomb that killed 27 people, including a 10-year-old girl, when it ripped through a church full of Sunday worshipers understood well how endemic bigotry in Egypt has left Christian lives at the whim of a regime that pays lip service to protecting them, armed Islamists who actively seek them harm, and a public that largely does not care.
2016-12-22.headline_main: Egypt’s Cruelty to Christians

Trump’s most prominent cabinet nominees — with their millions in assets and complex business arrangements — are moving unusually slowly through the government’s arduous financial disclosure examinations, threatening the quick start promised for the new administration and raising Democratic concerns that their confirmations could short-circuit customary ethical safeguards.

2016-12-22.abstract: Think of your liver as the unindulgent relative at your holiday party who doesn’t like the change in schedule and would rather be in bed.
2016-12-22.snippet: Think of your liver as the unindulgent relative at your holiday party who doesn’t like the change in schedule and would rather be in bed.
2016-12-22.lead_paragraph: Over the holidays, many of us will drink, stay up past bedtime, eat an extra slice of pie and sleep in. Fun as they are, these activities can tamper with our circadian rhythms, the feedback loops that sync our body’s functions to our external environment.

2016-12-22.abstract: In 2016, the industry’s evolution and embrace of streaming has encouraged listeners’ curiosity as artists have become experimental and adventurous.
2016-12-22.snippet: In 2016, the industry’s evolution and embrace of streaming has encouraged listeners’ curiosity as artists have become experimental and adventurous.
2016-12-22.lead_paragraph: Something unexpected happened near the top of the album charts this year: Pop stars were acting like artists. That is to say, they weren’t desperately chasing the broadest possible audience with the most surefire formulas; they weren’t calculating what would fit radio formats best. Instead, some of them grew eccentric and adventurous, impulsive and experimental, instinctive and personal — at times, bordering on avant-garde. And they found that listeners were willing to pay attention.
2016-12-22.headline_main: With Streaming, Musicians and Fans Find Room to Experiment and Explore

2016-12-22.lead_paragraph: The formidable creature looming over “A Monster Calls” is one of the more unnerving, impressive special-effects creations of the year. Whether it and the movie in general are too intense for younger children is something parents need to ask themselves. A PG-13 rating is sometimes an overreaction to a curse word or two, but here it’s a useful caution.
2016-12-22.headline_main: Review: ‘A Monster Calls,’ Offering a Boy a Lifeline

2016-12-22.lead_paragraph: At the wedding of Smriti Keshari and Matthew Danzico, which took place on Nov. 19 at Basilica Hudson in Hudson, N.Y., the groom mounted a horse and led a parade of guests who sang and danced their way to the site, in an Indian tradition known as a Baraat. A Hindu priest lit a fire to symbolize the illumination of the mind, knowledge and happiness. And the groomsmen and groomswomen wore top hats and cartoonish striped socks.
2016-12-22.headline_main: Instant Chemistry, Caught on Video

2016-12-22.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The ominous images in the video pile up, set to darkly urgent music. Refugees fleeing failed uprisings in the Middle East. Western diplomats and politicians cast as puppet masters of subversion in China. Chinese lawyers abjectly confessing to subversion in show trials. Protests erupting in Hong Kong.

2016-12-22.lead_paragraph: It was a welcome change to find my eyes glued not to the endlessly frustrating loop of the Krebs cycle, but instead to a portrait of 19th-century aristocrats in top hats and ball gowns. The afternoon, spent at a museum of British art, wasn’t a stolen escape from medical school. It was a required class.

2016-12-22.abstract: Across the spectrum of photo books published this year are pleasures to be discovered. Here are 10 of the best.
2016-12-22.snippet: Across the spectrum of photo books published this year are pleasures to be discovered. Here are 10 of the best.
2016-12-22.lead_paragraph: The term “photo book” is a bit of a catchall. Is a photo book a book consisting entirely or predominantly of photographs? Or is it a book that advances its argument largely by means of photographs? Do the photos have to have been taken with the intent of making art, or are other kinds of photographic documents permissible? If you want to make a fair-minded assessment, you have to consider small, self-published items as well as large, scholarly catalogs produced by mighty institutions. The good news is that all across this spectrum, there are pleasures to be discovered. For more than a month now, I’ve been sifting through the enormous pile of photo books that I’ve bought or received this year. Here are 10, in no particular order, that I found outstanding.
2016-12-22.headline_main: The Best Photo Books of 2016

2016-12-22.abstract: Like many encounters between the American military and residents of the island, the transfer of nearly 10,000 acres has stirred controversy.
2016-12-22.snippet: Like many encounters between the American military and residents of the island, the transfer of nearly 10,000 acres has stirred controversy.
2016-12-22.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Amid rising tensions over the American military presence on Okinawa, the United States officially returned nearly 10,000 acres of land on the northern part of the island to Japan on Thursday. It was the largest transfer of land since the United States returned Okinawa to Japan in 1972, at the end of postwar occupation.
2016-12-22.headline_main: U.S. Returns Some Okinawa Land to Japan, but Unease Endures

2016-12-22.abstract: An employee wonders how to respond after a boss appears to focus criticism on a single email out of thousands.
2016-12-22.snippet: An employee wonders how to respond after a boss appears to focus criticism on a single email out of thousands.
2016-12-22.lead_paragraph: I just completed my first year at a large company, or rather, at an affiliate that operates in a different market. I am relatively autonomous. My immediate supervisor has an understanding of my work, but the head of the overall business unit, by his own admission, has almost no idea what I actually do. In my midyear review, this higher-up made passing references to my “excellent” work but then focused on my adjustment to “company culture,” which he said needed improvement.

But the country has risen into their good graces after deciding to sever diplomatic ties with Taiwan, a self-governing island that China regards as a breakaway province.

2016-12-22.abstract: LeRoy Neiman and George Kalinsky were friends and artists with a common subject: Muhammad Ali. Their works can be seen at the New-York Historical Society.
2016-12-22.snippet: LeRoy Neiman and George Kalinsky were friends and artists with a common subject: Muhammad Ali. Their works can be seen at the New-York Historical Society.
2016-12-22.lead_paragraph: Muhammad Ali’s death in June was a reminder of what a brilliant muse he was, especially to photographers. He told us he was pretty, and he was right. But he was more than that. As images from his half-century of renown revealed anew, he had created an astonishing canvas simply by smiling, or by flicking a jab, preaching at a mosque, hitting the speed bag, glistening with sweat, rejecting entry into the military, goofing with the Beatles, screaming in mock-lunacy at Sonny Liston, taunting Joe Frazier and rope-a-doping with George Foreman. He rarely seemed to be offstage — or to take a bad picture.
2016-12-22.headline_main: Muhammad Ali: Drawn, Painted and Photographed

2016-12-22.abstract: The social-media giant is trying to combat the scourge of bogus stories on its site. But its methods suggest a continuation of its efforts to subsume the entire internet.
2016-12-22.snippet: The social-media giant is trying to combat the scourge of bogus stories on its site. But its methods suggest a continuation of its efforts to subsume the entire internet.
2016-12-22.lead_paragraph: Last Thursday, after weeks of criticism over its role in the proliferation of falsehoods and propaganda during the presidential election, Facebook announced its plan to combat “hoaxes” and “fake news.” The company promised to test new tools that would allow users to report misinformation, and to enlist fact-checking organizations including Snopes and PolitiFact to help litigate the veracity of links reported as suspect. By analyzing patterns of reading and sharing, the company said, it might be able to penalize articles that are shared at especially low rates by those who read them — a signal of dissatisfaction. Finally, it said, it would try to put economic pressure on bad actors in three ways: by banning disputed stories from its advertising ecosystem; by making it harder to impersonate credible sites on the platform; and, crucially, by penalizing websites that are loaded with too many ads.
2016-12-22.headline_main: Facebook’s Problem Isn’t Fake News — It’s the Rest of the Internet

2016-12-22.abstract: The women, part of the giant step for mankind, have their stories told in this movie directed by Theodore Melfi.
2016-12-22.snippet: The women, part of the giant step for mankind, have their stories told in this movie directed by Theodore Melfi.
2016-12-22.lead_paragraph: “Hidden Figures” takes us back to 1961, when racial segregation and workplace sexism were widely accepted facts of life and the word “computer” referred to a person, not a machine. Though a gigantic IBM mainframe does appear in the movie — big enough to fill a room and probably less powerful than the phone in your pocket — the most important computers are three African-American women who work at NASA headquarters in Hampton, Va. Assigned to data entry jobs and denied recognition or promotion, they would go on to play crucial roles in the American space program.
2016-12-22.headline_main: Review: ‘Hidden Figures’ Honors 3 Black Women Who Helped NASA Soar

2016-12-22.abstract: Also, grappling with the Christmas blues? A few ideas from Social Q’s. And an adult son’s holiday plans.
2016-12-22.snippet: Also, grappling with the Christmas blues? A few ideas from Social Q’s. And an adult son’s holiday plans.
2016-12-22.lead_paragraph: My husband and I went to a Hanukkah party, where I witnessed the hosts’ son (about 12) tease a younger girl whose mother is Latina. “Pack your bags,” he said. “Trump is going to send you back to Mexico.” The girl told her mother, who confronted the hosts; the boy denied it. And it was left as a misunderstanding. I didn’t report what I had heard. It felt like bad manners to elevate a children’s fight to the center of the party. My mother always said, “There’s a time and place for everything.” But my husband was horrified when I told him later. You?
2016-12-22.headline_main: Should I Stay Silent During One Child’s Populist Taunt of Another?

2016-12-22.snippet: A timeline of events in the life of the 24-year-old Tunisian suspected of carrying out the worst terrorist attack in Germany in decades.
2016-12-22.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Anis Amri, a Tunisian man who turned 24 on Thursday, is the chief suspect in a Europe-wide investigation into Germany’s worst terrorist attack in decades. His fingerprints and identity document were found inside a tractor-trailer that plowed into a Christmas market in Berlin on Monday, killing 12 people and injuring about 50 more. Here is a timeline of events in Mr. Amri’s life, drawn from government statements, interviews with officials and relatives, and news media accounts.
2016-12-22.headline_main: Anis Amri, Suspect in the Berlin Truck Attack: What We Know

2016-12-22.snippet: The ride-hailing giant expected to lose money this year, but economic theory suggests it’s handing its passengers a lot of value.
2016-12-22.lead_paragraph: Will Uber Technologies ever make money? The ride-share giant’s recent exit from the cutthroat Chinese market should help, but it may still lose $2.8 billion in earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, or Ebitda, this year, according to figures reported by The Information on Monday. Economic theory suggests Uber is handing its passengers lots of value. Turning a profit for investors, though, is a different story.
2016-12-22.headline_main: Uber’s Value to Riders Is Clear. To Investors, It May Prove More Elusive.

2016-12-22.abstract: Known for ingenious adaptations of ballet classics, Matthew Bourne tackles perhaps the most famous ballet film of all for his latest work in London.
2016-12-22.snippet: Known for ingenious adaptations of ballet classics, Matthew Bourne tackles perhaps the most famous ballet film of all for his latest work in London.
2016-12-22.lead_paragraph: LONDON — “Why do you want to dance?” the lordly impresario Boris Lermontov asks the young, beautiful dancer Victoria Page. “Why do you want to live?” she pipes back courageously. These are perhaps the most famous lines in perhaps the most famous ballet film of all: Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger’s 1948 “The Red Shoes,” a tale about the burning need to dance, the obsessive drive to create art and a heroine who is ultimately driven mad by those demands.
2016-12-22.headline_main: ‘The Red Shoes’ Takes the Stage

2016-12-22.lead_paragraph: It’s no secret that “La La Land,” the new movie from director Damien Chazelle (“Whiplash”) is a tribute to the flashy musicals of yesteryear. But the film is set in the present, following Mia, a would-be actress (Emma Stone) and Seb, an ambitious jazz musician (Ryan Gosling), both of whom are struggling to achieve their dreams in Los Angeles.
2016-12-22.headline_main: Three Classic Musical Scenes Evoked by ‘La La Land’

Trump said on Thursday that the United States should greatly “expand its nuclear capability,” appearing to suggest an end to decades of efforts by presidents of both parties to reduce the role of nuclear weapons in American defenses and strategy.

2016-12-22.abstract: The funniest almost-three-hour German comedy you will ever see, Maren Ade’s film is a thrilling act of defiance against the toxicity of doing what is expected.
2016-12-22.snippet: The funniest almost-three-hour German comedy you will ever see, Maren Ade’s film is a thrilling act of defiance against the toxicity of doing what is expected.
2016-12-22.lead_paragraph: Early in “Toni Erdmann” — by a wide margin the funniest almost-three-hour German comedy you will ever see — there is a brief discussion, conducted in a sterile modern office building in Bucharest, about the meaning of the English word “performance.” For Anca (Ingrid Bisu), a young Romanian employed by a global consulting firm, it refers to the way she does her job and, more than that, her ability to obey the norms and protocols of the corporate workplace. Her boss, she explains, gives her “a lot of feedback,” which is clearly a euphemism.
2016-12-22.headline_main: Review: In ‘Toni Erdmann,’ Dad’s a Prankster Trying to Jolt His Conformist Daughter

2016-12-22.abstract: In Martin Scorsese’s film, Jesuit priests in 17th-century Japan operate underground to keep their religion alive when they and their adherents are persecuted.
2016-12-22.snippet: In Martin Scorsese’s film, Jesuit priests in 17th-century Japan operate underground to keep their religion alive when they and their adherents are persecuted.
2016-12-22.lead_paragraph: Martin Scorsese’s “Silence” is a story of faith and anguish. It tells of a Portuguese Jesuit priest, Father Rodrigues, who in 1643 heads into the dark heart of Japan, where Christians are being persecuted — boiled alive, immolated and crucified. Rodrigues (Andrew Garfield) sets out to help keep the church alive in Japan, a mission that perhaps inevitably leads to God. The film’s solemnity is seductive — as is Mr. Scorsese’s art — especially in light of the triviality and primitiveness of many movies, even if its moments of greatness also make its failures seem more pronounced.
2016-12-22.headline_main: Review: Questions and Prayers Go Unanswered in Scorsese’s ‘Silence’

2016-12-22.abstract: In this film by Ken Loach, a working-class man in Britain is caught between the medical and employment bureaucracies.
2016-12-22.snippet: In this film by Ken Loach, a working-class man in Britain is caught between the medical and employment bureaucracies.
2016-12-22.lead_paragraph: Anyone who has spent 48 minutes on the phone waiting for a customer service representative can identify with the mounting impatience of the title character in Ken Loach’s scalding cinematic outcry, “I, Daniel Blake.”
2016-12-22.headline_main: Review: ‘I, Daniel Blake,’ Stuck on the Bureaucratic Hamster Wheel

2016-12-22.abstract: Ben Affleck directed and stars in this gangster movie set in the 1920s, in which he tries to pour new wine into a bullet-riddled vessel.
2016-12-22.snippet: Ben Affleck directed and stars in this gangster movie set in the 1920s, in which he tries to pour new wine into a bullet-riddled vessel.
2016-12-22.lead_paragraph: In “Live by Night,” Ben Affleck plays one of those romanticized antiheroes that movie stars love to suit up for, sometimes with a fedora. Over the decades these types have changed their looks and histories, but there’s a sameness to how they escape the law and the routine hum of everyday life; how they use guns ruthlessly or reluctantly; skip out on church yet live by their own moral code; and inevitably rise to become masters of their worlds, as well as of the most beautiful women in the room. They’re fantasies of power partly because no matter how hard this type falls, his power never truly corrupts.
2016-12-22.headline_main: Review: He Pledges Allegiance Only to His Tommy Gun, in ‘Live by Night’

2016-12-22.abstract: The 44-year-old founder of the cosmetics brand, who lives on a leafy NoLIta street, is always looking for inspiration, even on the weekends.
2016-12-22.snippet: The 44-year-old founder of the cosmetics brand, who lives on a leafy NoLIta street, is always looking for inspiration, even on the weekends.
2016-12-22.lead_paragraph: As the founder of the cosmetics brand Lipstick Queen, Poppy King, 44, is always looking for inspiration, even on the weekends. “There’s not an experience that I have where I’m not potentially looking to spark a lipstick concept,” she said. “I never turn off that lens: I can be in the subway or walking down the street and am still thinking of lipstick ideas.” The entrepreneur, born in Melbourne, Australia, has lived in a one-bedroom apartment on a leafy NoLIta street for the past 14 years.

2016-12-22.abstract: The Book Review’s On Poetry columnist picks his favorite books of the year.
2016-12-22.snippet: The Book Review’s On Poetry columnist picks his favorite books of the year.
2016-12-22.lead_paragraph: When you think of American poetry over the past year, the question that comes to mind is: Will Donald Trump limit himself to a single inaugural poet? And if so, will that poet be Ted Nugent? And if so, will he do a reading of “Cat Scratch Fever”? And if so, will this cause the seas to rise, the skies to darken, the mountains to tremble and the events of Ragnarok to unfold, with the great wolf Fenris devouring Odin the All-Father and even mighty Thor brought low, after slaying the world-encircling Midgard serpent? And if so, will Trump declare this to have been “Sad!”?
2016-12-22.headline_main: The Best Poetry of 2016

2016-12-22.lead_paragraph: Even as Ridgewood, Queens, undergoes rapid transformations as one of New York’s neighborhoods du jour, Rudy’s Bakery and Cafe, on Seneca Avenue, remains loyal to its old-school identity. The soda-shop signage and unflashy storefront seem to be working just fine for this 82-year-old business.

2016-12-22.abstract: This tree has shown itself to be an urban survivor, even among New York City’s asphalt slabs.
2016-12-22.snippet: This tree has shown itself to be an urban survivor, even among New York City’s asphalt slabs.
2016-12-22.lead_paragraph: The London plane tree is able to withstand the many assaults of urban life. It is often found squeezed tightly into tree pits surrounded by impermeable asphalt and concrete, making rain absorption difficult. Despite their potential size when fully grown, the trees adapt remarkably to cramped quarters, even while overshadowed by buildings and other structures. Often, they are pruned to within an inch of their lives to fit under phone lines or to avoid streetlights. They survive not only runoff from salted roads but also a consistent barrage of raw fertilizer by neighborhood cats and dogs.
2016-12-22.headline_main: London Plane: A Tree With Gritty Roots

2016-12-22.abstract: Nova struck out 52 batters and walked just three after being traded to Pittsburgh by the Yankees. He signed a three-year, $26 million contract, according to multiple reports.
2016-12-22.snippet: Nova struck out 52 batters and walked just three after being traded to Pittsburgh by the Yankees. He signed a three-year, $26 million contract, according to multiple reports.

2016-12-22.headline_main: Ivan Nova Is Said to Agree to 3-Year Deal to Stay With Pirates

2016-12-22.abstract: It is hard to know when or how much to get exercised over culinary cultural appropriation when it is class, rather than identity posturing, that is really at issue.
2016-12-22.snippet: It is hard to know when or how much to get exercised over culinary cultural appropriation when it is class, rather than identity posturing, that is really at issue.
2016-12-22.lead_paragraph: Were we to review the year in terms of gastronomic controversies, we might begin and end with the debate over chopped cheese. If your life in New York is purposely dull and cloistered, confined to the Caviar meal-delivery service, Showtime and the obsessive monitoring of Brooklyn real estate listings, then the furor over the sandwich — alternately known as chopped or chop cheese — may have escaped your notice entirely. If that is the case, you are, in effect, part of the problem, as disconnected as the reporter who ventured uptown and “discovered” the sandwich, a longtime offering at bodegas in the Bronx and Harlem, with the surprise of someone coming upon a new moon near Uranus.
2016-12-22.headline_main: Gentrification and Junk Food: Chopped-Cheese Edition

2016-12-23.abstract: Poland’s history puts its leader at odds with Putin. Yet their political styles are similar — an authoritarian streak cloaked in nationalism.
2016-12-23.snippet: Poland’s history puts its leader at odds with Putin. Yet their political styles are similar — an authoritarian streak cloaked in nationalism.
2016-12-23.lead_paragraph: PARIS — In 1987, at the height of Mikhail S. Gorbachev’s glasnost, I sat down in a Moscow theater with a few hundred others to watch a just-released somber film. Shot three years earlier by the Georgian director Tengiz Abuladze but immediately shelved, the film, “Repentance,” was a powerful allegorical critique of Stalinism in which a corpse refuses to stay buried. In the audience there was not a single dry eye. Finally the monstrosity of Joseph Stalin’s terror could be openly discussed. Sitting in the dark, I realized how painful those secrets, kept so long by millions of Soviet families, had been.
2016-12-23.headline_main: Stalin’s Lengthening Shadow

2016-12-23.lead_paragraph: Authoritarians with an animus against ethnic minorities are on the march across the Western world. They control governments in Hungary and Poland, and will soon take power in America. And they’re organizing across borders: Austria’s Freedom Party, founded by former Nazis, has signed an agreement with Russia’s ruling party — and met with Donald Trump’s choice for national security adviser.

2016-12-23.abstract: Jesus’ virgin birth is a holy miracle in Islam, too.
2016-12-23.snippet: Jesus’ virgin birth is a holy miracle in Islam, too.
2016-12-23.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Billions of Christians around the world are excited to celebrate Christmas this weekend. Those in the world’s second-largest religious community, Muslims, don’t share quite the same excitement. In a few Muslim-majority countries, like Saudi Arabia, Brunei and Somalia, Christmas celebrations are banned. In Turkey, my country, they are not illegal, but some Islamist groups still organize annual protests against Christmas trees and Santa Claus costumes, which they consider Western impositions.
2016-12-23.headline_main: Why It’s Not Wrong to Wish Muslims Merry Christmas

2016-12-23.snippet: The shape-shifting character actor reflects on his roles in “Office Space” and the “prescient” Amazon series “The Man in the High Castle.”
2016-12-23.lead_paragraph: You’ve seen Stephen Root far more than you might think. He’s the shape-shifting character actor you know you recognize, but can’t place. Of course, there’s his unforgettable creation from the cult classic “Office Space”: Milton, the stapler-obsessed arsonist hidden under extremely thick glasses, stilted speech and a pocket protector. But Mr. Root has mined a number of idiosyncratic veins over the past several decades, with memorable parts in films like “No Country for Old Men,” TV shows as disparate as “NewsRadio, “Louie” and “Boardwalk Empire,” and voice work in animated ones like “King of the Hill” and “Adventure Time.”

2016-12-23.lead_paragraph: There are grim passages in our lives when each day begins and ends with dread, when endurance is a form of victory. In one such time, when the life of someone I loved was hanging in the balance, I turned to reading for solace. The diagnosis was grave, the treatment arduous and life-threatening in itself. My days and nights were kaleidoscopes of terror: weekslong hospitalizations, middle-of-the-night sprints to emergency rooms, daylong drug infusions at clinics, beeping monitors, doctors’ verdicts.

2016-12-23.lead_paragraph: Q. I keep a ton of stuff in my Dropbox account, which is fine for my desktop computer with its spacious hard disk. I installed the Dropbox app on my ultrabook (instead of just logging in on the web), but it’s nearly filling up my laptop’s available drive space. Is there a way to link to just some of the files — and not everything in the Dropbox folder?

2016-12-23.abstract: In response to reader concerns, Janet Evanovich has toned down the swearing in some of her books — but not the Stephanie Plum series. “Turbo Twenty-Three,” the latest, is No. 9 in hardcover fiction.
2016-12-23.snippet: In response to reader concerns, Janet Evanovich has toned down the swearing in some of her books — but not the Stephanie Plum series. “Turbo Twenty-Three,” the latest, is No. 9 in hardcover fiction.
2016-12-23.lead_paragraph: Criminy: “Turbo Twenty-Three,” the latest entry in Janet Evanovich’s long-running series about the New Jersey bounty hunter Stephanie Plum, is No. 9 in its fifth week on the hardcover fiction list. Evanovich keeps herself busy, James Patterson style: Besides the salty Plum novels, which she writes on her own, she also hit the hardcover list in 2016 with two thrillers she co-wrote — “The Pursuit,” written with Lee Goldberg as part of the Fox and O’Hare series, and “Curious Minds,” written with Phoef Sutton as the debut of the Knight and Moon series. All three share Evanovich’s boisterous humor, but one thing separating the protagonists is their vocabulary, as the website MyCentralJersey.com observed in an interview last summer: “Your newest heroine, Riley Moon, despite two professional degrees from Harvard, never swears,” the reporter Tricia Vanderhoof pointed out. (You have to love that “despite.”) “Instead she says Crikes, Holy Moly, Crikey. . . . Why this quirk?”
2016-12-23.headline_main: The Story Behind This Week’s Best Sellers

2016-12-23.abstract: Attendance is dwindling at Santa’s Workshop in the Adirondacks, bypassed by the Interstate and thrill-ride-inspired attractions. But its biggest hurdle? Santa’s weakening hold on children.
2016-12-23.snippet: Attendance is dwindling at Santa’s Workshop in the Adirondacks, bypassed by the Interstate and thrill-ride-inspired attractions. But its biggest hurdle? Santa’s weakening hold on children.
2016-12-23.lead_paragraph: NORTH POLE, N.Y. — On a snowy shoulder of Whiteface Mountain in the Adirondacks, beyond hand-painted signs advertising “North Pole, N.Y.” and “Rides, Shops, Shows,” several parking attendants pushed a sedan, its tires spinning, into a packed lot. The car’s occupants spilled out, joining other families who high-stepped through snowdrifts — just about everyone smiling, some tossing snowballs — toward the entrance to Santa’s Workshop, a theme park from another era.
2016-12-23.headline_main: A Struggling Theme Park Asks: Do You Still Believe in Santa?

2016-12-23.lead_paragraph: Congressional reports can be a snooze. But that is not how I’d characterize Wednesday’s in-depth account of price gouging among prescription drug makers. The 130-page narrative prepared by the United States Senate Special Committee on Aging was juicy, detailing how four pharmaceutical companies have taken advantage of our health care system to enrich themselves and their executives, harming patients and taxpayers.

2016-12-24.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Less than two hours before announcing his resignation as president of the Soviet Union on Dec. 25, 1991, Mikhail S. Gorbachev placed a telephone call to President George H. W. Bush, who was celebrating Christmas with his grandchildren at Camp David.

2016-12-24.abstract: As part of my own Christian pilgrimage, I wondered why God became not just the author of the human drama but an actor in it.
2016-12-24.snippet: As part of my own Christian pilgrimage, I wondered why God became not just the author of the human drama but an actor in it.
2016-12-24.lead_paragraph: Early in my Christian pilgrimage, as a young man struggling to understand the implications of a story I had only a surface knowledge of, I stumbled onto a theological insight. For followers of Jesus, salvation was based not on his life so much as his death. Jesus could have been incarnated as a man and been crucified within days. That’s all that was needed for his death to serve as an atonement, but that’s not what happened. God clearly wanted to instruct us about how we should live in this life, too.
2016-12-24.headline_main: Humanizing Jesus

2016-12-24.lead_paragraph: SADKI-STROYEVKA, Ukraine — A cold wind whips through the streets. Vehicles that enter must drive through a foot-deep, moatlike bath of disinfectant, lest their tires track in disease. Computers raise and lower the levels of light to match circadian rhythms.

2016-12-24.snippet: Signing the free-agent slugger Edwin Encarnacion is a coup for Cleveland, which reached the World Series despite low payroll and attendance figures.
2016-12-24.lead_paragraph: The Cleveland Indians, a small-market team that came within one victory of a World Series title last month, have now added significant firepower to their lineup. And they did it, in what probably amounts to a surprise, by finding a way to reach an agreement with the right-handed slugger Edwin Encarnacion, one of the top free agents this winter.
2016-12-24.headline_main: After Coming Up Short, Indians Open Wallet to Add Edwin Encarnacion

2016-12-24.abstract: Shawn Harrington, who was in the 1994 movie “Hoop Dreams” and became a high school coach, has lost the use of his legs because of a 2014 shooting.
2016-12-24.snippet: Shawn Harrington, who was in the 1994 movie “Hoop Dreams” and became a high school coach, has lost the use of his legs because of a 2014 shooting.
2016-12-24.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The first truly great American sports documentary, it’s universally agreed, was “Hoop Dreams.” Released in 1994, it garnered immediate critical acclaim; Roger Ebert later called it the best film of the decade and “one of the great moviegoing experiences of my lifetime.” Its failure to be nominated for an Academy Award caused such an outcry that the process for nominating Oscar-worthy documentaries was eventually revamped.
2016-12-24.headline_main: A ‘Hoop Dreams’ Sequel, Written by Gun Violence

2016-12-24.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — When President Obama and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel met in September for the last time before Mr. Obama leaves office, the session was marked by forced smiles and strained jokes about playing golf in retirement, as if bygones were bygones after nearly eight years of clawing conflict.
2016-12-24.headline_main: For Obama and Netanyahu, a Final Clash After Years of Conflict

2016-12-24.lead_paragraph: BAYONNE, N.J. — Nicole Adamczyk’s drinking water used to slosh through a snarl of pipes dating from the Coolidge administration — a rusty, rickety symbol of the nation’s failing infrastructure.

2016-12-24.abstract: In Lancaster, Pa., where resettlement work dates back decades, volunteers and staff members from the Church World Service prepared a home for a family of new arrivals.
2016-12-24.snippet: In Lancaster, Pa., where resettlement work dates back decades, volunteers and staff members from the Church World Service prepared a home for a family of new arrivals.
2016-12-24.lead_paragraph: LANCASTER, Pa. — A dull gray house on a hillside has to become a home. Another Syrian family of refugees will be arriving soon, and this empty, echoing old place needs to be readied in welcome.
2016-12-24.headline_main: A Joyful Bustle to Get Ready for Guests: Syrian Refugees

2016-12-24.lead_paragraph: The Rev. Roderick Dwayne Belin, a senior A.M.E. Church leader, stood before a gathering of more than 1,000 pastors in a drafty Marriott ballroom in Naperville, Ill., this month and extolled the virtues of a Hollywood movie.

2016-12-24.abstract: Who could train women to run for office? The inside story of Hillary Clinton and a Texan named Betsey Wright.
2016-12-24.snippet: Who could train women to run for office? The inside story of Hillary Clinton and a Texan named Betsey Wright.
2016-12-24.lead_paragraph: It is too soon to know whether the unexpected outcome of Hillary Clinton’s presidential candidacy will inspire more women to run or dampen their aspirations. But either way, it is clear that she has, through her campaigns and career, helped create a political environment in which a woman could come so close to winning the presidency.
2016-12-24.headline_main: The Women Who Met Hillary, and Spotted a Future Political Star

2016-12-24.abstract: Six months after Brexit, the world of a Times reporter’s children remains inclusive, but she finds a changing Britain and feels her German heritage more than before.
2016-12-24.snippet: Six months after Brexit, the world of a Times reporter’s children remains inclusive, but she finds a changing Britain and feels her German heritage more than before.
2016-12-24.lead_paragraph: “Who are you?” I asked my daughter, curious how the concept of identity applied to a 5-year-old German-Welsh girl living in post-“Brexit” London.
2016-12-24.headline_main: Grappling With My Family’s Identity in a Post-‘Brexit’ Europe

2016-12-24.abstract: Of his illness, Bowles said, “Kidney stones, gallbladder, gallstones got stuck in the pipe.” After passing medical tests, he joined the team at its hotel.
2016-12-24.snippet: Of his illness, Bowles said, “Kidney stones, gallbladder, gallstones got stuck in the pipe.” After passing medical tests, he joined the team at its hotel.
2016-12-24.lead_paragraph: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Jets Coach Todd Bowles does not talk about injuries in much detail, but after Saturday’s 41-3 loss to New England, he made an exception — to discuss his own.
2016-12-24.headline_main: Todd Bowles Shakes Off Illness to Oversee Jets’ Blowout Loss

2016-12-24.abstract: Mr. Sellers was a leading figure in NASA’s scientific research programs, flying to the International Space Station on the space shuttle Atlantis in 2002 and 2010, and on Discovery in 2006.
2016-12-24.snippet: Mr. Sellers was a leading figure in NASA’s scientific research programs, flying to the International Space Station on the space shuttle Atlantis in 2002 and 2010, and on Discovery in 2006.
2016-12-24.lead_paragraph: Piers J. Sellers, a climate scientist who flew to the International Space Station three times in NASA’s shuttle program, became a leading figure in the agency’s scientific research initiatives and continued while terminally ill to devote himself to the challenges posed by global warming, died on Friday in Houston. He was 61.
2016-12-24.headline_main: Piers J. Sellers, Climate Scientist and Space Station Astronaut, Dies at 61

2016-12-24.abstract: In a dog-friendly co-op, can the board evict a breed with a bad reputation?
2016-12-24.snippet: In a dog-friendly co-op, can the board evict a breed with a bad reputation?
2016-12-24.lead_paragraph: Q. I am the president of the board of a co-op in East Harlem, Manhattan, that permits dogs of any size or breed. But after a rental tenant  got a pit bull, the board received several complaints from residents who say the dog whines and pounds the floor. One is terrified of the breed and complains almost daily, calling for the dog to be removed. What am I supposed to do? I don’t think the dog can be removed just because of the stereotypes surrounding its breed. But how do I tell the pet owner that she must keep her dog quiet?
2016-12-24.headline_main: When a Neighbor Brings Home a Pit Bull

2016-12-24.abstract: A couple with their two children left behind staggering poverty and bloodshed in Uganda. They needed more than a little help to get settled in California.
2016-12-24.snippet: A couple with their two children left behind staggering poverty and bloodshed in Uganda. They needed more than a little help to get settled in California.
2016-12-24.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Pascal Serugendo was only 7 when he first fled his violence-torn village in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Separated from his family, he followed a group of grown-ups also escaping the deadly war over the country’s gold and diamonds.
2016-12-24.headline_main: Beginning a New Life in America, With Mentors by Their Side

2016-12-24.abstract: Anis Amri’s nephew and two others were arrested by the Tunisian authorities, one day after Mr. Amri was killed by an Italian police officer.
2016-12-24.snippet: Anis Amri’s nephew and two others were arrested by the Tunisian authorities, one day after Mr. Amri was killed by an Italian police officer.
2016-12-24.lead_paragraph: The Tunisian authorities have arrested three men “linked to the perpetrator of the terrorist attack” at a Berlin Christmas market, including the suspect’s nephew, the government said in a statement on Saturday.
2016-12-24.headline_main: 3 Men Linked to Berlin Attack Suspect Are Arrested in Tunisia

2016-12-24.abstract: New companies offer “concierge” services as traditional firms add new technology.
2016-12-24.snippet: New companies offer “concierge” services as traditional firms add new technology.
2016-12-24.lead_paragraph: Adam Pittenger, who has moved six times in six years, shares his home in Hoboken, N.J., with his girlfriend and a roommate. With his frequent firsthand experience as a guide, he started a company this year to help make moving less of a chore.
2016-12-24.headline_main: Start-Ups Seek to Take Some of the Pain Out of Moving

2016-12-24.abstract: Spark Networks, which owns JDate, ChristianMingle and other niche sites, has been jolted by executive turnover and upheaval in the industry.
2016-12-24.snippet: Spark Networks, which owns JDate, ChristianMingle and other niche sites, has been jolted by executive turnover and upheaval in the industry.
2016-12-24.lead_paragraph: Not many people have heard of Spark Networks, but far more are familiar with what it owns: JDate, ChristianMingle and a host of other sites like SilverSingles.com and BlackSingles.com.

2016-12-24.abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon share my attitude about a seasonal event.
2016-12-24.snippet: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon share my attitude about a seasonal event.
2016-12-24.lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — I’m sure there was a time when I was thrilled by the first snow of the season, but after more than 20 years of shoveling my walkways and driveway, I’m pretty much over it. These days, I dream of palm trees and more temperate climates, and yet here I am. Still shoveling. [That is not a euphemism for her writing. — Ed.] [Thank you for clearing that up. — D. A.]
2016-12-24.headline_main: Variety: Acrostic

2016-12-24.abstract: As Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu seeks to move past the Palestinian conflict and improve regional relations, Mr. Trump’s views may bring the issue back to the fore.
2016-12-24.snippet: As Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu seeks to move past the Palestinian conflict and improve regional relations, Mr. Trump’s views may bring the issue back to the fore.
2016-12-24.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — On the wall of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s office is a giant floor-to-ceiling map with Israel at its center. Mr. Netanyahu likes staring at the map. He regales visitors with stories about how Israel has made friends with so many of the countries shown, some nearby, others far away.
2016-12-24.headline_main: U.S. Transition Puts Israeli Focus Back on Palestinians

2016-12-24.abstract: Mr. Trump has agreed to shut his charity, weighed a plan for an outside monitor to oversee the Trump Organization and ended some international business projects.
2016-12-24.snippet: Mr. Trump has agreed to shut his charity, weighed a plan for an outside monitor to oversee the Trump Organization and ended some international business projects.
2016-12-24.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Realizing that his presidency could face potentially crippling questions over conflicts of interest, Donald J. Trump and his family are rushing to resolve potential controversies — like shuttering foundations and terminating development deals — even as the president-elect publicly maintains that no legal conflicts exist.
2016-12-24.headline_main: Denying Conflict, Trump Family Tries to Resolve Potential Problems

2016-12-24.abstract: He won N.CA.A. titles and the Stanley Cup by emphasizing conditioning, nutrition and fundamentals, an approach that met with rolled eyes a generation ago but is now commonplace.

2016-12-24.abstract: It’s an Old World culinary practice that has been all but forgotten by American Jews. Let’s bring it back.
2016-12-24.snippet: It’s an Old World culinary practice that has been all but forgotten by American Jews. Let’s bring it back.
2016-12-24.lead_paragraph: Christmas dinner has it all: a well-balanced feast with a main dish — turkey, ham or goose — a range of sides, delicious desserts and eggnog to top it off. And Hanukkah? Jews typically enjoy latkes smothered in sour cream or applesauce (my preference), jelly doughnuts, chocolate coins and, consequently, eight days of pounding Tums.
2016-12-24.headline_main: Goose: A Hanukkah Tradition
