2016-12-29.lead_paragraph: Even before President Obama’s decision last week to abstain on a United Nations Security Council resolution condemning Israeli settlements, it was safe to assume that the Israeli government was eagerly awaiting his departure. In the eyes of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Mr. Obama — who skipped Israel on his first trip to the Middle East and later undertook secret nuclear talks with Iran — seemed unable to appreciate the depth of Israel’s security needs or the difficulties of Mr. Netanyahu’s domestic politics.

2016-12-29.abstract: Online services offer many alcohol-related films. Here are some in the “What Am I Doing With My Life?” and “Well, That Wasn’t So Bad, Was It?” categories.
2016-12-29.snippet: Online services offer many alcohol-related films. Here are some in the “What Am I Doing With My Life?” and “Well, That Wasn’t So Bad, Was It?” categories.
2016-12-29.lead_paragraph: In the parts of the world that experience winter as winter, New Year’s Day is special. On a sunny cold New Year’s Day here in New York, the piercing light and the sharp air can serve as a metaphorical — and metaphysical — reproach, even if you’re stone cold sober; it’s not desirable hangover weather. In the years before my domestication, my New Year’s Day hangover cure involved more alcohol and a trip home to New Jersey, where I and some similarly afflicted friends would gorge on regional comfort food — deep-fried hot dogs and fries all the way at Rutt’s Hut in Clifton, perhaps, or a cheeseburger and onion rings from the sadly departed Hearth on Route 46. Only after completing this ritual would we consider a movie, preferably something loud and empty.
2016-12-29.headline_main: Oh, My Aching Head: Movies for the Soused or Now Sober

2016-12-29.abstract: A holiday meal ends on a sour note, a mother is struggling to get to work on time, and a bride-to-be is sick of hearing “At Last” at weddings.
2016-12-29.snippet: A holiday meal ends on a sour note, a mother is struggling to get to work on time, and a bride-to-be is sick of hearing “At Last” at weddings.
2016-12-29.lead_paragraph: After a big holiday meal, my fiancé and I watched as our hostess wrapped up the remaining turkey without offering us any to take home. We were shocked! Had the roles been reversed, we would never dream of sending guests home without enough turkey for at least a couple of sandwiches. (It’s not as if there was a shortage. We watched her fill two large Tupperware containers with bird.) Was our hostess rude, or are we imposing our Midwestern code on East Coast friends?
2016-12-29.headline_main: No Leftovers for You

2016-12-29.lead_paragraph: From the opening pages of his colossal biography of Grigory Rasputin, the historian Douglas Smith dismantles many of the myths enshrouding the monk who exerted inordinate influence over Nicholas II and Alexandra, emperor and empress of Russia, during the twilight of the Romanov dynasty a century ago.
2016-12-29.headline_main: ‘Rasputin’ Unravels the Myths of the ‘Mad Monk’

2016-12-29.abstract: The American Dance Platform is bringing together eight companies at the Joyce Theater.
2016-12-29.snippet: The American Dance Platform is bringing together eight companies at the Joyce Theater.
2016-12-29.lead_paragraph: Starting on Tuesday, Jan. 3, the American Dance Platform will gather eight companies from around the country that have a range of influences: jazz, ballet, salsa, modern, Indian and Afro-Cuban dance. The week, curated by Alice B. Adams, of the Kennedy Center in Washington, includes events like an epic duet by 16 choreographers; a dance comparing human relations to a chess game; a tribute to cosmic energy; a satirical depiction of comic book superheroes; and evocations of water — both its grandeur and scarcity. Succeeding programs, each with two attractions, offer companies like Contra-Tiempo (Los Angeles), RAWdance (San Francisco), Ragamala Dance Company (Minneapolis), Davalois Fearon Dance (New York), Dallas Black Dance Theater and Lucky Plush Productions (Chicago). These dancers have brains in their heads as well as steps in their feet. (Through Jan. 8, Joyce Theater; joyce.org/performances.)
2016-12-29.headline_main: How Many Choreographers Does It Take to Create a Duet? 16

2016-12-29.abstract: Bartlett Sher and Gianandrea Noseda discuss their production of Gounod’s “Roméo et Juliette,” which opens at the Metropolitan Opera on New Year’s Eve.
2016-12-29.snippet: Bartlett Sher and Gianandrea Noseda discuss their production of Gounod’s “Roméo et Juliette,” which opens at the Metropolitan Opera on New Year’s Eve.
2016-12-29.lead_paragraph: It might seem like impertinence, not to say blasphemy, to suggest that Shakespeare could ever be bettered. But Bartlett Sher, the director of a new production of Gounod’s “Roméo et Juliette” that opens at the Metropolitan Opera on New Year’s Eve, is willing to go there.
2016-12-29.headline_main: A New Take on Romeo and Juliet’s Ball, Balcony, Bed and Tomb

2016-12-29.abstract: The baritone Stephen Salters and the Taíno singer Irka Mateo bring to life the music that might have been heard on the streets of New Amsterdam.
2016-12-29.snippet: The baritone Stephen Salters and the Taíno singer Irka Mateo bring to life the music that might have been heard on the streets of New Amsterdam.
2016-12-29.lead_paragraph: There’s no shortage of engravings and paintings that illustrate what Lower Manhattan looked like in colonial times. But what did it sound like? As St. Paul’s Chapel continues to celebrate the 250th anniversary of its founding, an ambitious music program at Trinity Wall Street conjures sounds from the past as part of its Time’s Arrow festival, which begins Sunday, Jan. 1.
2016-12-29.headline_main: Conjuring Musical and Colonial Ghosts

2016-12-29.abstract: The melodic and theatrical punk duo of Liv Bruce and Ben Hopkins will be playing Joe’s Pub.
2016-12-29.snippet: The melodic and theatrical punk duo of Liv Bruce and Ben Hopkins will be playing Joe’s Pub.
2016-12-29.lead_paragraph: PWR BTTM, the melodic and theatrical punk duo of Liv Bruce and Ben Hopkins, are masters of presentation. Onstage and in videos, the pair allow their simple, effective songs, which often hover around two minutes, to burst with color and queerness from glam rock and drag traditions. (“I Wanna Boi,” from the group’s 2015 debut full-length, “Ugly Cherries,” is a wonderful example.)

2016-12-29.abstract: Scorsese and Tarantino, then Barry Jenkins and his “Moonlight.”
2016-12-29.snippet: Scorsese and Tarantino, then Barry Jenkins and his “Moonlight.”
2016-12-29.lead_paragraph: Like Janus, the Film Society of Lincoln Center is pretty adept at looking backward and forward at the same time. It begins 2017 by concluding a survey of 40 years of movies at least partly defined by their use of Steadicam shots. The series runs through Tuesday, Jan. 3, but cinephiles stirring on New Year’s Day will find a last seasonal gift: an indelible lineup of Paul Thomas Anderson’s “Boogie Nights”; Martin Scorsese’s “Goodfellas”; and Quentin Tarantino’s “Pulp Fiction.”
2016-12-29.headline_main: This Past Provides a Nice Prologue at Film Society of Lincoln Center

2016-12-29.abstract: This film’s director, Eve Marson, looks at the ethics of prescribing pain medication and at Dr. William Hurwitz, who was prosecuted for narcotics distribution.
2016-12-29.snippet: This film’s director, Eve Marson, looks at the ethics of prescribing pain medication and at Dr. William Hurwitz, who was prosecuted for narcotics distribution.
2016-12-29.lead_paragraph: Accompanied by a tinkling piano and soft lighting, Dr. William Hurwitz, the subject of Eve Marson’s catchily titled and infuriatingly vague documentary, “Dr. Feelgood: Dealer or Healer?,” faces the camera with a benign smile. For someone who has endured two criminal trials for narcotics distribution and served almost five years in prison, he seems remarkably at peace.
2016-12-29.headline_main: Review: ‘Dr. Feelgood: Dealer or Healer?’ It’s Not a Simple Question

2016-12-29.abstract: This ballet company, already full of talent, finds still more in George Balanchine’s holiday classic.
2016-12-29.snippet: This ballet company, already full of talent, finds still more in George Balanchine’s holiday classic.
2016-12-29.lead_paragraph: In recent years, New York City Ballet’s corps has been a wellspring of talent, bubbling up to refresh and replenish a company already in fine fettle. The 2014 and 2015 seasons of “George Balanchine’s The Nutcracker” brought a flood of six new Sugarplum Fairies (notably Emilie Gerrity and Unity Phelan) from the corps. This December has brought new interpreters of the ballet’s four next most important roles: Dewdrop, Drosselmeier, the Fairy’s Cavalier and Marzipan.
2016-12-29.headline_main: Fresh Dewdrops for New York City Ballet’s ‘Nutcracker’

2016-12-29.abstract: The “Voulkos: The Breakthrough Years” exhibition at the Museum of Arts and Design shows just how quickly and deftly he reinvented ceramic art.
2016-12-29.snippet: The “Voulkos: The Breakthrough Years” exhibition at the Museum of Arts and Design shows just how quickly and deftly he reinvented ceramic art.
2016-12-29.lead_paragraph: Calling Peter Voulkos a ceramist is a bit like calling Jimi Hendrix a guitarist. The charismatic, rebellious sculptor and teacher was a genuine rock star of his medium, a trained potter who went on to violate every rule of pot-making — often before a live audience. His sculptures started out clearly enough as polite, wheel-thrown vessels but evolved into nervy and transgressive abstract paintings, looming behemoths fired in industrial-size kilns, precarious assemblages and live-wire performances (no ritual immolation but lots of smashing and dropping of plates and vases).
2016-12-29.headline_main: Peter Voulkos, an Influential Sculptor Who Broke the Rules

2016-12-29.snippet: The National Portrait Gallery, which is displaying a series of such pictures, will soon show a 1989 studio photograph of a self-confident 40-something Donald J. Trump.
2016-12-29.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An inescapable fact of American elections is that a new president’s mug may soon be in your face, nonstop. For Donald J. Trump, a corollary is that he, like all newcomers to office, can keep company with the mugs of his choosing, decorating the Oval Office with presidential portraits — typically the official ones in the collections on view at the White House and the National Portrait Gallery.

2016-12-29.abstract: The New Yiddish Rep presents a revival of the 1907 Sholem Asch play that scandalized New York with its portrayal of prostitution and same-sex romance.
2016-12-29.snippet: The New Yiddish Rep presents a revival of the 1907 Sholem Asch play that scandalized New York with its portrayal of prostitution and same-sex romance.
2016-12-29.lead_paragraph: Questions of guilt and retribution gnaw ceaselessly at the heart of Yankl (Shane Baker), the central character in Sholem Asch’s “God of Vengeance,” which is being given a timely revival by the New Yiddish Rep at LaMaMa. A pious Orthodox Jew, Yankl makes his living in what remains a highly unorthodox profession: He owns a brothel that sits below the apartment in which his family lives.

2016-12-29.snippet: Itching to get up off the couch and spurn ‘New Year’s Rockin’ Eve’? Here’s a list of shows, from hip-hop to cabaret. And then there’s those naked comedians.
2016-12-29.lead_paragraph: AFROJACK Afrojack has been hovering near the top tier of global D.J.s for a few years now, but he’s never quite connected as an artist on his own terms (like, say, the successful but uninspired Calvin Harris). But this year, he released “Gone,” an extremely temperate and sneakily effective collaboration with Ty Dolla Sign, and maybe there’s more where that came from. At 8 p.m., the Gallery in the Dream Downtown, Manhattan; NYCNewYears.com. (Jon Caramanica)

2016-12-29.lead_paragraph: Kamasi Washington began this year literally hobbled: After breaking an ankle on tour in Europe, he followed doctor’s orders and canceled a series of shows. Still, that pause hardly slowed the onrushing momentum that Mr. Washington, a commandingly charismatic tenor saxophonist and bandleader, has gathered since the release of his momentous debut, “The Epic.”

2016-12-29.snippet: Recalling a singular Hollywood star and an era we won’t see again.
2016-12-29.lead_paragraph: Nobody like Debbie Reynolds is ever happening at the movies again. Who’ll be as plucky? Who’ll work as hard to stay as morally pure? Who the hell is gonna be named Debbie? These days, when we talk about “showbiz,” we have to adjust for deflation, because it just doesn’t mean as much as it did when Ms. Reynolds was a star.
2016-12-29.headline_main: The Unsinkable Debbie Reynolds

2016-12-29.abstract: The Buffalo Board of Education asked Mr. Paladino to leave over his remarks about the Obamas. He responded, “It’s going to be a very combative year.”
2016-12-29.snippet: The Buffalo Board of Education asked Mr. Paladino to leave over his remarks about the Obamas. He responded, “It’s going to be a very combative year.”
2016-12-29.lead_paragraph: The Buffalo Board of Education on Thursday demanded that Carl Paladino resign from his post on the board after making racist comments about President and Michelle Obama last week. If he refuses to step down, the board will ask the state education commissioner to remove him, it said in a resolution.
2016-12-29.headline_main: After Paladino’s Racist Remarks, Buffalo School Board Demands He Resign

2016-12-29.abstract: “Simon Starling: At Twilight” at Japan Society treats 20th-century English-speaking poets like demigods and shows how cross-cultural modernism can be.
2016-12-29.snippet: “Simon Starling: At Twilight” at Japan Society treats 20th-century English-speaking poets like demigods and shows how cross-cultural modernism can be.
2016-12-29.lead_paragraph: “Modernism is our antiquity,” the historian T. J. Clark wrote in “Farewell to an Idea,” his 1999 eulogy for the art of the last century. By which he meant: As Greece and Rome served as the base line for Western culture from the Renaissance onward, modernism itself had become our model and myth, to be reinterpreted at will but never really understood. Spend half a day in Chelsea, and you will see few gods and heroes — but you will trip over archives of failed utopian collectives, photos of crumbling tower blocks, rebooted avant-garde dances and all sorts of fragments of the recent past. Ulysses may be dead, but “Ulysses” endures.
2016-12-29.headline_main: Simon Starling: Modernism Gazing Into the Past

2016-12-30.snippet: Edwards, a onetime defensive coordinator, developed standout quarterbacks and innovative offensive schemes as a head coach and led Brigham Young to the 1984 national title.
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: LaVell Edwards, who took over a perennially lackluster Brigham Young University football program in 1972, orchestrated a string of winning seasons with innovative passing attacks run by All-American quarterbacks and coached the Cougars to the 1984 national championship, died on Thursday at his home in Provo, Utah. He was 86.
2016-12-30.headline_main: LaVell Edwards, Coach Who Led B.Y.U. to a Football Title, Dies at 86

2016-12-30.abstract: Navajo and Hopi leaders support the coal company, whose mine has provided jobs on reservations, but other tribe members say an expansion would destroy burial grounds.
2016-12-30.snippet: Navajo and Hopi leaders support the coal company, whose mine has provided jobs on reservations, but other tribe members say an expansion would destroy burial grounds.
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: KAYENTA, Ariz. — The world’s largest coal company, Peabody Energy, is seeking federal approval to expand its mine on Navajo and Hopi land in northern Arizona, a move supported by tribal leaders. But many other tribe members say the expansion would destroy burial grounds and pre-Columbian ruins and are opposing it in court.
2016-12-30.headline_main: Peabody Energy and Native Americans in Dispute Over Mining in Arizona

2016-12-30.abstract: The New York Police Department has taken a step in the right direction by allowing officers of the Sikh faith to wear beards and turbans while in uniform.
2016-12-30.snippet: The New York Police Department has taken a step in the right direction by allowing officers of the Sikh faith to wear beards and turbans while in uniform.
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department sent a message of religious tolerance on Wednesday when Commissioner James O’Neill announced a policy change that will allow the city’s officers who observe the Sikh faith to wear beards and turbans while in uniform, if the turban is blue and displays the department’s shield.
2016-12-30.headline_main: Protecting the Rights of Our Protectors

But they will also be greeted by something that has only recently become a regular feature of the city’s security infrastructure: strategically positioned garbage trucks loaded with sand.

2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: PARANÁ, Argentina — An Argentine court reopened an investigation on Thursday into accusations that former President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner sought a secret deal with Iran in connection with the 1994 bombing of a Jewish center in Buenos Aires. The original case was filed by Alberto Nisman, the prosecutor whose mysterious death in 2015 convulsed the country.

2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: In a speech this week laying out the Obama administration’s parameters for a final peace agreement between Israel and Palestine, Secretary of State John Kerry stated what has been obvious to most observers for many years: that Israel’s construction of Jewish settlements on occupied Palestinian land has all but destroyed the two-state solution. Unfortunately, Mr. Kerry’s speech offers far too little, and comes much too late.
2016-12-30.headline_main: John Kerry and Israel: Too Little and Too Late

On the North Island, which is shaped a bit like a bird’s head, we were moving slowly toward the tip of the beak.

2016-12-30.snippet: Will Trump really kill Obamacare?
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: If James Comey, the F.B.I. director, hadn’t tipped the scales in the campaign’s final days with that grotesquely misleading letter, right now an incoming Clinton administration would be celebrating some very good news. Because health reform, President Obama’s signature achievement, is stabilizing after a bumpy year.

Or, as the Metropolitan Transportation Authority put it in a news release, “the historic, on-time opening of the Second Avenue subway.”

2016-12-30.abstract: Thousands of recent veterans unfairly received less-than-honorable discharges. President Obama can immediately help them upgrade their discharges.
2016-12-30.snippet: Thousands of recent veterans unfairly received less-than-honorable discharges. President Obama can immediately help them upgrade their discharges.
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: Kristofer Goldsmith spent the end of his teenage years photographing mutilated bodies. Mr. Goldsmith knew that he would face bullets and bombs when he enlisted in the Army shortly after Sept. 11, and like almost every soldier of his generation, he volunteered to serve with the understanding that he would go to war. He made sergeant in just over two years and spent an entire year in Baghdad.

2016-12-30.abstract: Another refugee banished by Australia to Manus Island has died, the latest victim of a form of dehumanization that threatens the world.
2016-12-30.snippet: Another refugee banished by Australia to Manus Island has died, the latest victim of a form of dehumanization that threatens the world.
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: The dead refugee had a name. But even in death Australia did not want to humanize him. For years now he had been no more than a registration number — BRF063 — under the country’s cruel refugee deterrence system known as “offshore processing.”
2016-12-30.headline_main: Australia’s Death by Numbers

Yankielun, an engineer who has written about igloo construction. “Igloos are the most specialized form of a snow shelter, and you need a special type of snow to do it right. The truly appropriate snow is somewhere where there is not a freeze-and-thaw cycle. That kind of weather destroys the structural integrity of the snow.” But even though ideal igloo-making environments are closer to the polar regions, it’s not impossible to replicate good conditions elsewhere.

2016-12-30.abstract: At 80, she has spent years alone in her Russian village.
2016-12-30.snippet: At 80, she has spent years alone in her Russian village.
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: Last June, as there was no poplar fluff to bother me yet in Novaya Usman, I got in the habit of spending my days outside. Novaya Usman is a small village in southern Russia near the city of Voronezh, and I have lived here for more than a decade. I am now 80, and at my age it is hard to walk for very long, so I would sit on a lavochka, a wooden bench, near my house and watch the people go by. I also daydreamed about life back at Almaty, thousands of miles away. If nostalgia became unbearable, I headed back home.
2016-12-30.headline_main: Looking for a Friend in Old Age

2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: The Italian composer and pianist Ludovico Einaudi, 61, is one of the world’s most-streamed classical artists, with more followers on Spotify (about 740,000) than Mozart (680,000). His music, by turns minimal and lush, incorporates an array of influences from Bach to rock to West African kora music. While sold-out audiences across Europe find something sublime in his searching style, some classical critics disagree — like Ben Beaumont-Thomas of The Guardian, who says it’s nothing more than the “dashed-off poignancy of an Instagrammed sunset.”
2016-12-30.headline_main: Ludovico Einaudi, a Classical Artist for the YouTube Age

2016-12-30.abstract: John Grisham, whose “The Whistler” is No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list, says: “I still pull for the underdog. I still like the little guy.”
2016-12-30.snippet: John Grisham, whose “The Whistler” is No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list, says: “I still pull for the underdog. I still like the little guy.”
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: Star Power: This week’s lists reflect book sales for the period ending Dec. 24, which means you’ll find lots of famous novelists on the fiction side of the ledger: In publishing as in home electronics, brand names sell well for the holidays. They know it, too. Here’s John Grisham — whose thriller “The Whistler” remains No. 1 in its ninth week on the hardcover fiction list — describing his target audience in a November interview with Slate: “First of all, she’s female, because two-thirds of all books are bought by women. She’s going to buy it during the Christmas season, because 35 percent of all books are sold during the Christmas season. I would guess she’s probably going to be over 40, because they buy more books than under 40. And that kind of narrows it down. That’s probably my typical reader.” In the same interview, Grisham said he often writes from a sense of injustice about a given subject — don’t be surprised if he tackles student debt in a future thriller — and he gave vent, just a bit, to his political views. The short version: He doesn’t think much of Donald Trump. The slightly longer, more diplomatic version: “I still pull for the underdog. I still like the little guy, especially when the little guy is getting screwed by the big guy: the government, a corporation, an issue, whatever. . . . But you’ve got to be careful with your audience, because they don’t always share my politics. You can’t be intrusive with your politics in popular fiction, when you’re trying to entertain people. I really have to watch that, and I do watch it. I don’t feel a responsibility to write a book next year that might change something. My responsibility next year is to write a book that will entertain.”
2016-12-30.headline_main: The Story Behind This Week’s Best Sellers

2016-12-30.abstract: A Postal Service ad has revived interest in a 1953 Christmas novelty hit by the former child star Gayla Peevey. (She did get the hippopotamus.)
2016-12-30.snippet: A Postal Service ad has revived interest in a 1953 Christmas novelty hit by the former child star Gayla Peevey. (She did get the hippopotamus.)
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: This year’s holiday advertising campaign for the United States Postal Service featured a little girl’s stunningly infectious musical plea: “I Want a Hippopotamus for Christmas.” (And, as she explains, “Only a hippopotamus will do.”) The ditty was, perhaps, unfamiliar to many listeners, but it penetrated the mind space of the unwary at warp speed — and stayed there. Resistance was futile.

2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: NATE, India — Ronnie Screwvala sat cross-legged early last month on the floor of a three-room schoolhouse here in Nate, a village about 100 miles from Mumbai, the city of his birth where he built a billion-dollar media conglomerate. Watching a group of children playing with colorful educational games, Mr. Screwvala, a boyish-looking 54-year-old, appeared as wide-eyed and engaged as the students.
2016-12-30.headline_main: After Building a Media Empire, What’s Next? Lifting One Million From Poverty

2016-12-30.abstract: The police said that the wife of Kyriakos Amiridis, the Greek ambassador to Brazil, had her lover kill him and set his body on fire.
2016-12-30.snippet: The police said that the wife of Kyriakos Amiridis, the Greek ambassador to Brazil, had her lover kill him and set his body on fire.
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The killing of the Greek ambassador was shocking even by the standards of this crime-weary city: Investigators say his wife had him murdered in a home they owned in Rio by her lover, a police officer, who then set the diplomat’s remains on fire.
2016-12-30.headline_main: Wife and Her Lover Are Arrested in Killing of Greek Envoy in Brazil

2016-12-30.abstract: Four seasoned Times reporters offer a guide to the coming year.
2016-12-30.snippet: Four seasoned Times reporters offer a guide to the coming year.
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: Here’s something we did not predict a year ago: that Russia would hack the Democratic National Committee to undermine faith in the 2016 election and that the winner of that race, President-elect Donald J. Trump, would shrug off the entire episode by telling the country to “move on” as he stood next to Don King, a boxing promoter and convicted felon.
2016-12-30.headline_main: Predictions for a Trump Presidency

2016-12-30.abstract: The Zaatari refugee camp in Jordan is one of the largest Syrian camps in the world. In the fall, we visited the camp live with our audience. Here’s what we heard from the refugees and from you.
2016-12-30.snippet: The Zaatari refugee camp in Jordan is one of the largest Syrian camps in the world. In the fall, we visited the camp live with our audience. Here’s what we heard from the refugees and from you.

2016-12-30.abstract: In the fall, we visited one of the largest Syrian refugee camps in the world while live on Facebook. Here’s what we heard from the refugees and from you.
2016-12-30.snippet: In the fall, we visited one of the largest Syrian refugee camps in the world while live on Facebook. Here’s what we heard from the refugees and from you.
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: In September, we visited a Syrian refugee camp while live on Facebook, and brought The New York Times’s audience along. We went to the Zaatari refugee camp in Jordan, one of the largest Syrian camps in the world, after our audience said in countless comments that they wanted to see and interact with Syrian refugees.
2016-12-30.headline_main: Syrian Refugees on the War, Their Camp, and Your Questions

2016-12-30.abstract: For some first-time buyers, renting might actually be cheaper, both in the short- and long-term.
2016-12-30.snippet: For some first-time buyers, renting might actually be cheaper, both in the short- and long-term.
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: Q. My husband and I are in our 30s and used to rent in Brooklyn. After we had a baby, we moved to the suburbs. We’re now thinking about buying a house, but I can’t wrap my mind around how it would be financially advantageous. In Port Washington on Long Island, we pay $2,600 a month in rent for a beautiful apartment. For a barely livable house, we would pay at least $3,600 a month, not counting the additional expenses of ownership. From my estimates, we will save $12,000 a year if we continue to rent. What am I missing?
2016-12-30.headline_main: Does It Pay to Buy a House in the Suburbs?

2016-12-30.abstract: Mr. Pettibon, whose drawings spin pop culture into anarchic creations, is the subject of a retrospective at the New Museum starting in February.
2016-12-30.snippet: Mr. Pettibon, whose drawings spin pop culture into anarchic creations, is the subject of a retrospective at the New Museum starting in February.
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: In his energetic drawings of baseball greats, Hollywood legends, comic book heroes and rock stars, of drug addicts, bikers and gangsters, Charles Manson and J. Edgar Hoover, Raymond Pettibon gives us the full sweep of the American social landscape.
2016-12-30.headline_main: Raymond Pettibon: Pictures, Literary Voices and Surfers, Too

2016-12-30.abstract: The nationalistic remarks in Beijing came as China was negotiating a possible deal to improve ties with the Vatican.
2016-12-30.snippet: The nationalistic remarks in Beijing came as China was negotiating a possible deal to improve ties with the Vatican.
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A top Chinese official suggested that Catholic churches in China should be run independently of the Roman Catholic Church, the state news media reported on Friday, striking a nationalistic tone as the country negotiates a possible deal to improve relations with the Vatican.
2016-12-30.headline_main: Catholic Churches in China Should Be Independent of Vatican, Official Says

2016-12-30.abstract: They were one of a kind, and yet they were all of us.
2016-12-30.snippet: They were one of a kind, and yet they were all of us.
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: Some years ago I had the privilege of a long evening with Carrie Fisher, starting at her house in Beverly Hills and proceeding to a nearby restaurant, and she talked so expansively — about her memories of “Star Wars,” about her electric shock treatments, about Diet Coke, about everything — that I didn’t come away with just a few impressions of her. I came away with a few hundred.
2016-12-30.headline_main: Debbie Reynolds and Carrie Fisher: Hollywood’s Mother-Daughter Fable

2016-12-30.abstract: A drop in their numbers has prompted an international team to call for changing the animal’s status from vulnerable to endangered.
2016-12-30.snippet: A drop in their numbers has prompted an international team to call for changing the animal’s status from vulnerable to endangered.
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: The cheetah, as swift as it is in the hunt, will not be able to outrun the threats to its survival without new conservation efforts, according to an international team of researchers who reported their findings in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.
2016-12-30.headline_main: Cheetahs in Danger of Extinction, Researchers Say

2016-12-30.abstract: Obama has laid all the groundwork Trump needs for a crackdown on reporters.
2016-12-30.snippet: Obama has laid all the groundwork Trump needs for a crackdown on reporters.
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If Donald J. Trump decides as president to throw a whistle-blower in jail for trying to talk to a reporter, or gets the F.B.I. to spy on a journalist, he will have one man to thank for bequeathing him such expansive power: Barack Obama.
2016-12-30.headline_main: If Donald Trump Targets Journalists, Thank Obama

2016-12-30.abstract: This rural community finds itself in the glare of attention as home to Mr. Trump’s weekend getaway and the headaches that may come with it.
2016-12-30.snippet: This rural community finds itself in the glare of attention as home to Mr. Trump’s weekend getaway and the headaches that may come with it.
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: BEDMINSTER, N.J. — The local roads were closed, with Secret Service agents, the state police and local law enforcement on patrol. Deep in a protective bubble, President-elect Donald J. Trump was holding court in his living quarters not long after his election, receiving would-be members of his future administration at his country club. A crush from the news media waited outside for a photo opportunity. But there was little traffic, no protesters and few gawkers — except for a herd of horses, idly chewing grass.
2016-12-30.headline_main: Sleepy New Jersey Town Wakes to a New Identity: Trump’s ‘Camp David North’

2016-12-30.abstract: Originally scheduled for the spring, “Bright Lights: Starring Carrie Fisher and Debbie Reynolds” will now be shown on Jan. 7.
2016-12-30.snippet: Originally scheduled for the spring, “Bright Lights: Starring Carrie Fisher and Debbie Reynolds” will now be shown on Jan. 7.
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: HBO announced on Friday that it was moving up the debut of “Bright Lights: Starring Carrie Fisher and Debbie Reynolds,” a documentary about the daughter and mother who died this week. The film was to air in the spring; it will now be shown on HBO next Saturday night, Jan. 7.
2016-12-30.headline_main: A Documentary on Fisher and Reynolds to Air Sooner on HBO

2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: When you visit David Burke’s bright, airy two-bedroom penthouse apartment in a high-rise rental building in Fort Lee, N.J., you can chow down on the pastrami salmon, the candied bacon and the burrata, all prepared by Mr. Burke, the celebrated chef whose newest restaurant, Tavern 62 by David Burke, opened in mid-October on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.
2016-12-30.headline_main: David Burke, Celebrity Chef: Collector or Hoarder?

2016-12-30.abstract: A truce went into effect at midnight Thursday, but was marred by sporadic fighting even as it could lead to peace negotiations next month in Kazakhstan.

2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Amid scattered reports of clashes and airstrikes, a cease-fire between the Syrian government and rebel groups tentatively took hold across the country on Friday, signaling a fragile peace that could lead to talks aimed at ending more than five years of fighting.
2016-12-30.headline_main: Cease-Fire in Syria Frays but Holds, Giving Hope to Peace Talks

2016-12-30.abstract: What is the prognosis for renters now that the long-awaited line is scheduled to open?
2016-12-30.snippet: What is the prognosis for renters now that the long-awaited line is scheduled to open?
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: First proposed nearly a century ago, the Second Avenue subway, or at least a portion of it between 63rd and 96th Streets, is finally scheduled to be up and running in the new year. An extension of the Q line will add new stations at 72nd, 86th and 96th Streets. One might expect that a decade of noisy construction would have kept rents down along this stretch of Second Avenue, but a recent study by StreetEasy indicates otherwise.
2016-12-30.headline_main: Rents and the Second Avenue Subway

2016-12-30.abstract: The financial security of the very wealthy, contrasting with more general geopolitical nervousness, looks set to be the default mode of the art world for some time.
2016-12-30.snippet: The financial security of the very wealthy, contrasting with more general geopolitical nervousness, looks set to be the default mode of the art world for some time.
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: LONDON — As we enter 2017, and the inauguration of Donald J. Trump looms, many sectors of the global economy are wondering what impact his presidency will have on their business. The art market is one of them.
2016-12-30.headline_main: Trump and the Art Market: A Feel-Good Factor?

2016-12-30.abstract: Liu Shao-chi, the wife of China’s chief of state, says she betrayed Chairman Mao’s trust.
2016-12-30.snippet: Liu Shao-chi, the wife of China’s chief of state, says she betrayed Chairman Mao’s trust.
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — For Lady Bird Johnson to announce suddenly that she has been plotting to overthrow the U.S. government is unimaginable. Yet an admission of that magnitude has been made by the wife of the Peking regime’s chief of state, Liu Shao-chi, in one of the most remarkable documents to emerge from the convulsions currently shaking Communist China.
2016-12-30.headline_main: 1966: China’s First Lady Admits She Plotted Against Maoism

2016-12-30.abstract: Researchers studied bubbles from the grapevine to the glass, learning more about their properties and how that effervescence affects flavor.
2016-12-30.snippet: Researchers studied bubbles from the grapevine to the glass, learning more about their properties and how that effervescence affects flavor.
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: A cork pops. The sudden change in pressure releases carbon dioxide trapped in the bottle. Bubbles form. They ride along as liquid falls from the bottle to your champagne glass. Once inside, a million of them cling against its edges before rising to the top and bursting — like supernovas — as soon as they hit the air. The explosion releases tiny droplets of liquid, and for a moment, your mouth contains a universe. The droplets dart across it like shooting stars that crash against your tongue. The aromatic landing of the fermented grapes is sharp, crisp, sweet, dry, delicate, delightful. This may be how you welcome 2017.
2016-12-30.headline_main: A Universe of Bubbles in Every Champagne Bottle

2016-12-30.abstract: In mid-December, the Venezuelan government surprised its citizens by withdrawing from circulation the 100-bolívar note, its largest and most used bill, with only 72 hours’ warning. Here’s what happened next.
2016-12-30.snippet: In mid-December, the Venezuelan government surprised its citizens by withdrawing from circulation the 100-bolívar note, its largest and most used bill, with only 72 hours’ warning. Here’s what happened next.

2016-12-30.snippet: A round table of pop experts discuss the year in tracks, from Maren Morris’s “Rich” to Rihanna’s “Sex With Me.”

2016-12-30.abstract: Economics teaches caution about where and when markets can work without government intervention. Education is one such case.
2016-12-30.snippet: Economics teaches caution about where and when markets can work without government intervention. Education is one such case.
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: The odds are good that privatizing education will be part of the agenda for President-elect Donald J. Trump’s administration. The Republican platform calls for increasing the role of banks in giving out student loans. And Mr. Trump and the platform advocate an expansion of both vouchers, which enable students to attend the private school of their choice with government funds, and charter schools.
2016-12-30.headline_main: Free Market for Education? Economists Generally Don’t Buy It

2016-12-30.abstract: Annie Moore was the first immigrant through Ellis Island. I followed a path from Ireland to New York a lot later.
2016-12-30.snippet: Annie Moore was the first immigrant through Ellis Island. I followed a path from Ireland to New York a lot later.
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: In January 2014, a girl from Cobh, Ireland (formerly known as Queenstown) journeyed across the Atlantic, skipped rosy-cheeked off an airplane at John F. Kennedy International Airport to start her new life. That was me, compensating for my indoor ghost face with too much blush in a shade aspirationally entitled “orgasm.” In January 1892, a girl from Queenstown (now known as Cobh) skipped rosy-cheeked off a boat at Ellis Island to start her new life. That was Annie Moore, flushed with embarrassment at the unexpected fuss being made of her by the officials on the island. She was the first immigrant through the new processing center that opened its doors on Jan. 1 of that year.
2016-12-30.headline_main: Two Irish Girls Who Made It to New York

2016-12-30.abstract: Fashion and music merged seamlessly in the supermodel-studded video, a collaboration whose stylish energy still moves. Naomi Campbell, Tatjana Patitz, Candis Cayne and more reminisce.
2016-12-30.snippet: Fashion and music merged seamlessly in the supermodel-studded video, a collaboration whose stylish energy still moves. Naomi Campbell, Tatjana Patitz, Candis Cayne and more reminisce.
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: Pop music and fashion never met cuter than in George Michael’s “Freedom! ’90” video. Sure, other catwalk favorites starred in music videos during that era, and fashion photographers like Steven Meisel and Herb Ritts were recruited by stars such as Madonna, Chris Isaak and Janet Jackson to burnish their visuals.
2016-12-30.headline_main: George Michael’s Freedom Video: An Oral History

2016-12-30.abstract: Visitors of Rockefeller Center's ice rink mostly dressed to ward off the cold, but a few stylistic flourishes added some brio to the proceedings.
2016-12-30.snippet: Visitors of Rockefeller Center's ice rink mostly dressed to ward off the cold, but a few stylistic flourishes added some brio to the proceedings.
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: The first snow of the season had fallen, but that couldn't keep a mix of New Yorkers and visitors away from one of the city’s most iconic holiday attractions: the ice rink at Rockefeller Center, which recently had its 80th anniversary. Visitors mostly dressed to ward off the cold, but this being New York, a few stylistic flourishes added some brio to the proceedings. We spoke to a few skaters and spectators about what they were wearing on a recent Saturday afternoon, a week before Christmas. This is what they told us.
2016-12-30.headline_main: Holiday Style, on and Off the Ice, at the Rockefeller Center Rink

2016-12-30.abstract: The Spice Islands can teach us about the sins and virtues of globalization.
2016-12-30.snippet: The Spice Islands can teach us about the sins and virtues of globalization.
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: GOA, India — For many years the word “globalization” was used as shorthand for a promised utopia of free trade powered by the world’s great centers of technological and financial innovation. But the celebratory note has worn thin. The word is now increasingly invoked to explain a widespread recoiling from a cosmopolitan earth. People in many countries are looking nostalgically backward, toward less connected, supposedly more secure times.
2016-12-30.headline_main: What Nutmeg Can Tell Us About Nafta

2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: As troubled pension funds go, the New York State Teamsters Conference Pension and Retirement Fund, with some $1.3 billion in assets, is by no means the largest. Neither is it in the direst financial shape, even though just 44.8 percent of its obligations are funded.

2016-12-30.abstract: Taking a moment to consider the reasons New Yorkers may feel less terrible about the year that was and what’s ahead.
2016-12-30.snippet: Taking a moment to consider the reasons New Yorkers may feel less terrible about the year that was and what’s ahead.
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: Yes, 2016 was a terrible year — for politics, civility, discourse, death. New Yorkers were forced to create bandwidth in their brains to accommodate the reality that one of the city’s most storied and ridiculed tabloid personalities would lead the free world. David Bowie left his adopted city, and us. Homelessness rose. The Big Apple Circus, a beloved New York institution that brought the performing arts to poor children at no cost, had to shut down when it could not generate sufficient philanthropic interest. Skyrocketing costs forced the restaurant Da Silvano to close after 41 years in Greenwich Village. We  could go on at biblical length before we got to the downsizing of Gracious Home, the Manhattan purveyor of upscale home goods. But let’s not. Let us instead, for the moment, consider the reasons we, as New Yorkers, may feel less terrible about the year that was and what’s ahead:
2016-12-30.headline_main: A Bad Year for New Yorkers. However ...

2016-12-30.abstract: Many worry that with the shutdown of Met Food, lower-income residents will not be able to afford pricier fare at Whole Foods and other gourmet markets.
2016-12-30.snippet: Many worry that with the shutdown of Met Food, lower-income residents will not be able to afford pricier fare at Whole Foods and other gourmet markets.
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: SoHo offers a bounty of food — each block in this Manhattan neighborhood seems to feature artisanal chocolatiers selling single origin cacao, juice shops extruding vegetables for $9 a bottle and stores peddling cupcakes and Cronuts. Yet while high-end delicacies with gold bullion prices abound, humbler places to buy a jar of nonartisanal peanut butter or a sack of plain old gluten-full flour are much harder to find.
2016-12-30.headline_main: Fears of Food Desert in High-End SoHo as Grocery Closes

2016-12-30.abstract: The deaths of David Bowie, Prince and Leonard Cohen drew considerable attention in a year that also claimed Muhammad Ali and Fidel Castro.
2016-12-30.snippet: The deaths of David Bowie, Prince and Leonard Cohen drew considerable attention in a year that also claimed Muhammad Ali and Fidel Castro.
2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: Death may be the great equalizer, but it isn’t necessarily evenhanded. Of all the fields of endeavor that suffered mortal losses in 2016 — consider Muhammad Ali and Arnold Palmer in sports and the back-to-back daughter-mother Hollywood deaths of Carrie Fisher and Debbie Reynolds — the pop music world had, hands down, the bleakest year.
2016-12-30.headline_main: Among Deaths in 2016, a Heavy Toll in Pop Music

2016-12-30.lead_paragraph: There is no easy way to sum up the rich smorgasbord that was culture in 2016. But — to stay with a culinary metaphor — this sampling of our arts photography offers a taste. These images take us behind the scenes to watch the Nigerian artist Laolu Senbanjo use the actress Danielle Brooks as his canvas. They make us privy to private moments, like those of a photo-averse Howard Stern in his studio; of Metropolitan Opera musicians taking a backstage poker break; of Taylor Mac applying makeup in front of his dressing room mirror. And they bring us closer to celebrities like Julia Louis-Dreyfus, Judith Light and Tony Bennett.
2016-12-30.headline_main: In the Moment: Photographs From 2016

2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: In 2013, the Boy Scouts of America ended its ban on openly gay youths participating in its activities.
2016-12-31.headline_main: Cub Scouts Kick Out Transgender Boy in New Jersey

2016-12-31.snippet: A fresh start? Be careful what you wish for.

2016-12-31.abstract: A judge refused a request for more freedom by Ng Lap Seng, a billionaire who was allowed to stay in his luxury apartment in Manhattan until his trial on bribery charges.
2016-12-31.snippet: A judge refused a request for more freedom by Ng Lap Seng, a billionaire who was allowed to stay in his luxury apartment in Manhattan until his trial on bribery charges.
2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: When the Chinese billionaire Ng Lap Seng was arrested in New York on bribery charges in 2015, a judge allowed him to await trial not in a jail cell but in a spacious apartment in Midtown Manhattan, with GPS monitoring and 24-hour armed security guards — all at Mr. Ng’s expense.
2016-12-31.headline_main: Awaiting Trial in a Gilded Cage, a Rich Defendant Is Denied a Walk in the Park

2016-12-31.abstract: Amid an economic collapse, a wave of violence is afflicting the country.
2016-12-31.snippet: Amid an economic collapse, a wave of violence is afflicting the country.
2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: Amid an economic collapse, a wave of violence is afflicting the country.
2016-12-31.headline_main: Venezuela’s Deadliest Year

2016-12-31.abstract: It is easy to become numb to suffering. Feeling empathy for individual victims can overcome the numbness.
2016-12-31.snippet: It is easy to become numb to suffering. Feeling empathy for individual victims can overcome the numbness.
2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: There is a legend about the comedian W. C. Fields as he lay dying in his hospital bed, surrounded by family. It was winter in New York City, and from outside came the sound of a newsboy shouting, “Wuxtry! Wuxtry! Stock market prices fall!” Stirred out of his stupor, Fields signaled those assembled to his bedside and whispered, “Poor little urchins out there — undernourished, no doubt improperly clad — something’s got to be done about them, something’s got to be done.” He dozed off, but seconds later, opened his eyes again. “On second thought,” he said, “Screw ’em.”
2016-12-31.headline_main: To Make the World Better, Think Small

2016-12-31.abstract: Spinraza, a “life-changing” drug for spinal muscular atrophy, will cost as much as $750,000 for the first year of treatment and $375,000 annually after that.
2016-12-31.snippet: Spinraza, a “life-changing” drug for spinal muscular atrophy, will cost as much as $750,000 for the first year of treatment and $375,000 annually after that.
2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration has approved the first drug to treat patients with spinal muscular atrophy, a savage disease that, in its most severe form, kills infants before they turn 2.
2016-12-31.headline_main: Costly Drug for Fatal Muscular Disease Wins F.D.A. Approval

2016-12-31.abstract: Loopholes in regulations let stretch limousines cruise without seatbelts and protections.
2016-12-31.snippet: Loopholes in regulations let stretch limousines cruise without seatbelts and protections.
2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: Eight young women out on a tour of Long Island wineries had both safety and comfort in mind when they booked a stretch limousine for their pre-wedding celebration in the summer of 2015. But four of them died and two were severely injured when the driver attempted a U-turn on a busy county highway and the long limousine was broadsided in traffic.
2016-12-31.headline_main: The Lethal Allure of Stretch Limos

2016-12-31.abstract: There is something about celebrity mothers and daughters like Debbie Reynolds and Carrie Fisher that captures the imagination in a way that famous father-sons do not.
2016-12-31.snippet: There is something about celebrity mothers and daughters like Debbie Reynolds and Carrie Fisher that captures the imagination in a way that famous father-sons do not.
2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: For anyone who loves the spotlight, mothering can be an ideal role — for a while. The mother is a singular star to her baby, whose gaze follows her around the room with the watchfulness of an obsessive fan. For the stars Carrie Fisher and Debbie Reynolds, that dynamic seemed to linger well into Ms. Fisher’s childhood: Ms. Fisher was the reverent observer, her mother the adored and observed.
2016-12-31.headline_main: Debbie Reynolds and Carrie Fisher, a Mother-Daughter Act for the Ages

2016-12-31.abstract: Under international pressure, Moscow still does not admit to the responsibility of the highest levels of government.
2016-12-31.snippet: Under international pressure, Moscow still does not admit to the responsibility of the highest levels of government.
2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: For a moment there it looked as if Russia had finally fessed up about its gigantic sports doping operation, even though a senior official’s acknowledgment of an “institutional conspiracy” in an interview with Rebecca Ruiz of The Times was coupled with the usual whining about how Russia was being pilloried for what everybody does. But then the official, as well as the minister of sports, came back and said the comment was taken out of context. And just like that, the matter was back to square one.
2016-12-31.headline_main: Russia’s Contorted Denials on Doping

2016-12-31.abstract: A century ago, a battalion on its way to the European front played in a league with top players. Though the experiment fizzled, it helped change the sport.
2016-12-31.snippet: A century ago, a battalion on its way to the European front played in a league with top players. Though the experiment fizzled, it helped change the sport.
2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: In Canada, the kinship between hockey and war is implicit. Both (of course) stoke patriotic pride, and there’s the recognition (maybe) that the vivid game that remains closest to the national heart reflects the confusion and desperate violence of the battlefield, while also (somehow) naturally honoring warrior values of bravery and perseverance.
2016-12-31.headline_main: A Quirk of Canadian History: When War and Hockey Shared the Ice

2016-12-31.abstract: Bill Cosby’s lawyers said publicity about the case had tainted any prospective jury in Montgomery County, Pa., where the trial is to start in June.
2016-12-31.snippet: Bill Cosby’s lawyers said publicity about the case had tainted any prospective jury in Montgomery County, Pa., where the trial is to start in June.
2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Bill Cosby asked a Pennsylvania judge on Friday to change the location or jury pool for his coming criminal trial on sexual assault charges, arguing that intense publicity surrounding the case has tainted any prospective jury in the county where the trial is scheduled to start in June.
2016-12-31.headline_main: Cosby Lawyers Ask Judge to Change Trial Location

2016-12-31.abstract: Mr. Cash wrote about the English novelist Laurence Sterne, and his biography of the 18th-century English radical John Wilkes was a Pulitzer finalist.
2016-12-31.snippet: Mr. Cash wrote about the English novelist Laurence Sterne, and his biography of the 18th-century English radical John Wilkes was a Pulitzer finalist.
2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: Arthur H. Cash, who wrote a definitive two-volume biography of the English novelist Laurence Sterne and became a Pulitzer Prize finalist in 2007 for his biography of the 18th-century English radical John Wilkes, died on Thursday in Watch Hill, R.I. He was 94.
2016-12-31.headline_main: Arthur H. Cash, Writer of British Biographies, Dies at 94

2016-12-31.abstract: Their matchup with the Columbus Blue Jackets is the first in the four major North American sports leagues between teams with streaks of at least 12 wins.
2016-12-31.snippet: Their matchup with the Columbus Blue Jackets is the first in the four major North American sports leagues between teams with streaks of at least 12 wins.
2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL — Since its founding in 1917, the N.H.L. has never had a game like Saturday’s matchup between the Columbus Blue Jackets and the Minnesota Wild at Xcel Energy Center: a regular-season matchup of two teams with winning streaks of at least 12 games.
2016-12-31.headline_main: Collision of 12-Game Winning Streaks Proves Rare for N.H.L., or Any League

2016-12-31.abstract: President Obama’s decision to expel 35 Russian diplomats was provocative, but gamesmanship on both sides involves familiar calculations, former intelligence officers say.
2016-12-31.snippet: President Obama’s decision to expel 35 Russian diplomats was provocative, but gamesmanship on both sides involves familiar calculations, former intelligence officers say.

2016-12-31.abstract: The Kremlin’s payment of a hefty state fine in the Czech Republic last spring, and the Czech president’s support for Russia, spur cries of influence-buying.
2016-12-31.snippet: The Kremlin’s payment of a hefty state fine in the Czech Republic last spring, and the Czech president’s support for Russia, spur cries of influence-buying.

2016-12-31.abstract: In addition to creating the popular plastic cup, Mr. Hulseman helped to invent a coffee cup lid that may be just as prevalent.
2016-12-31.snippet: In addition to creating the popular plastic cup, Mr. Hulseman helped to invent a coffee cup lid that may be just as prevalent.

2016-12-31.snippet: On leaving 2016 behind.
2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: Let’s pretend we’re in some cosmic therapist’s office, in a counseling session with the year 2016. We are asked to face the year and say something nice about it. Just one or two things.

2016-12-31.abstract: The vehicles’ occupants, who appeared to be mostly middle-aged men and women, would not lower their windows to speak to the reporters.
2016-12-31.snippet: The vehicles’ occupants, who appeared to be mostly middle-aged men and women, would not lower their windows to speak to the reporters.
2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: UPPER BROOKVILLE, N.Y. — Seven miles from here, an old-world mansion known as the Killenworth estate became, briefly, a center of international intrigue on Thursday as reporters began descending on the property, long a weekend retreat for Russian diplomats. President Obama had just announced that he would be closing a “Russian compound” in New York that had been used for intelligence gathering — and several administration officials pointed to Killenworth, which is in Glen Cove, as the target in New York.
2016-12-31.headline_main: Diplomatic Vehicles Vacate Russia’s Long Island Estate

2016-12-31.abstract: Jeff Chen sees us out of 2016.
2016-12-31.snippet: Jeff Chen sees us out of 2016.
2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Hello all! I feel so honored to be the Wordplay column’s baby new year for 2017! How sad it is that in mere hours we must bid this fabulous year, as I’m sure we all must agree we’ve had, adieu. Although behind the scenes here IRL I confess to having gotten a bit grizzled.
2016-12-31.headline_main: Not Around the Bend

2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: It’s time to say goodbye to 2016. Somehow, we made it through a divisive election season and an agonizing number of celebrity deaths (not to mention catastrophes around the world). The general sentiment seems to be: Good riddance to this year. Here is how television networks are ringing in the new year — a better one, let’s hope.

2016-12-31.abstract: Prosecutors accused Moon Hyung-pyo of ordering a pension fund to back the deal, which helped ensure that control of Samsung passed from its chairman to his son.
2016-12-31.snippet: Prosecutors accused Moon Hyung-pyo of ordering a pension fund to back the deal, which helped ensure that control of Samsung passed from its chairman to his son.
2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — A former cabinet minister was arrested Saturday on charges that he illegally pressured the national pension fund to approve a merger between two Samsung subsidiaries, a deal that helped ensure that control of South Korea’s most powerful conglomerate passed from its chairman to his son.
2016-12-31.headline_main: Korean Official Charged With Illegally Swaying Samsung Merger Vote

2016-12-31.abstract: Mr. Mathur tries to get away from his restaurant work, but it rarely works. When he can, he likes to kick back with his wife and daughter for Bollywood-style TV programming.
2016-12-31.snippet: Mr. Mathur tries to get away from his restaurant work, but it rarely works. When he can, he likes to kick back with his wife and daughter for Bollywood-style TV programming.
2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: After working 14-hour shifts six days a week as the executive chef and owner of Fine Indian Dining, a hospitality group that operates six Indian restaurants in Manhattan, including the recently opened Sahib in Curry Hill (around Lexington Avenue and 28th Street), Hemant Mathur tries to take Sundays off, but it rarely works. “I inevitably end up working at least half the day,” he said. Mr. Mathur, 49, does manage to spend time with his wife, Surbhi Sahni, 41, a pastry chef who also runs Bittersweet NYC, and their daughter, Soumyaa, 13. They live in Jackson Heights, Queens, where Mr. Mathur has lived since he immigrated from India nearly two decades ago.
2016-12-31.headline_main: How Hemant Mathur, Indian Restaurateur, Spends His Sundays

Book people mixed with movie people: Under a dense black acacia tree, the writer Amy Wilentz chatted with the television producer Nicole Yorkin; the historian Ed Larson rubbed elbows with the film producer Sean Daniel at the bar.

2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The two-minute cartoon opens with a folksy jingle and a smiling bobblehead of President Xi Jinping, dimpled and cherubic. 2016-12-31.abstract: If the Chinese government really commits to combating the ivory trade, then the price of ivory could collapse. Criminal organizations and poachers will then abandon the business.
2016-12-31.snippet: If the Chinese government really commits to combating the ivory trade, then the price of ivory could collapse. Criminal organizations and poachers will then abandon the business.
2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — In the past 10 years, tens of thousands of elephants have been slaughtered across Africa to feed China’s insatiable appetite for ivory. Entire herds from Gabon to Tanzania have disappeared. Even baby elephants have been killed for their tiny stubs of ivory. Scientists have said that the very survival of the species is in China’s hands.
2016-12-31.headline_main: Closing China’s Ivory Market: Will It Save Elephants?

2016-12-31.abstract: Mrs. Dukakis, a former first lady of Massachusetts, credits the treatment with saving her life, and she and her husband work to promote electroconvulsive therapy.
2016-12-31.snippet: Mrs. Dukakis, a former first lady of Massachusetts, credits the treatment with saving her life, and she and her husband work to promote electroconvulsive therapy.
2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: BROOKLINE, Mass. — When Michael Dukakis lost the presidential election in 1988, his wife, Kitty, felt as if she had been squashed in a compactor, all the air forced out of her. Her even-keeled husband went back to work as governor of Massachusetts; she started binge drinking.
2016-12-31.headline_main: Kitty Dukakis, a Beneficiary of Electroshock Therapy, Emerges as Its Evangelist

Trump tweeted just before Secretary of State John Kerry discussed the Israeli-Palestinian conflict last week. He added: “They used to have a great friend in the U.S., but …”

2016-12-31.abstract: Richard Silvestri scrambles a teeny whiner.
2016-12-31.snippet: Richard Silvestri scrambles a teeny whiner.
2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: It’s so nice to start a new year with a cryptic; they’re very artisanal, I think, finely crafted little jewel boxes of puns and clever verbal sleights of hand. It’s impossible to solve one while on end-of-year autopilot (or with a hangover!) and you’re bound to feel a frisson of satisfaction when figuring out a particularly clever entry, and a little admiration for its constructor, all positive vibes for 2017.
2016-12-31.headline_main: Variety: Cryptic Crossword

2016-12-31.abstract: How I overestimated the strength of both political parties.
2016-12-31.snippet: How I overestimated the strength of both political parties.
2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: EVERY January I write a column exploring my faulty analysis and failed prophecies from the preceding year. After last year’s installment, in which I explained how I had underestimated a certain celebrity tycoon, I received a note from Trump Tower — a clipping of the column, scrawled over with a markered note:
2016-12-31.headline_main: Confessions of a Columnist

2016-12-31.abstract: Vladimir Putin may look like a master tactician now for his role in the Syrian truce, but issues that derailed past cease-fires remain unresolved.
2016-12-31.snippet: Vladimir Putin may look like a master tactician now for his role in the Syrian truce, but issues that derailed past cease-fires remain unresolved.
2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: It was hard to greet the announcement last week of a new cease-fire in Syria without wariness. In six years of fighting, more than 400,000 people have been killed and entire cities devastated. This is a conflict that wouldn’t have happened, or lasted so long, save for the cynical brutality of President Bashar al-Assad and his chief allies, Russia and Iran.
2016-12-31.headline_main: Can Russia Make Peace as Well as War?

2016-12-31.abstract: Australians talk openly about painful history at public events. Americans might try the same.
2016-12-31.snippet: Australians talk openly about painful history at public events. Americans might try the same.
2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: The first time I heard it I was jet-lagged. I’d flown 20 hours to Byron Bay in Australia from New York, and was sitting on a stage with other American authors under a tent in the rain. We were in that pocket of the world for a writers’ festival, and before our panel discussion began, a volunteer welcomed the soggy audience of more than 200 people and mentioned that the land was originally part of an indigenous nation. This, an outright mention of a displaced population, connecting the space to a time before colonialism, was something I’d never experienced before. In Australia, it’s called an “acknowledgment of country.”
2016-12-31.headline_main: What Does It Mean to Acknowledge the Past?

2016-12-31.abstract: Booted from the Trump transition, the New Jersey governor is back home, dealing with problems he thought he had escaped.
2016-12-31.snippet: Booted from the Trump transition, the New Jersey governor is back home, dealing with problems he thought he had escaped.
2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: After a disastrous showing in the Republican presidential primaries and getting booted from the Trump transition team, Gov. Chris Christie returned home last month to the comfort of his power base in Trenton, only to find old statehouse allies brandishing pitchforks and torches, not the legislative favors he had hoped for.
2016-12-31.headline_main: Chris Christie’s Book of Hubris

2016-12-31.abstract: In 2017 we need to focus on substance, not celebrity.
2016-12-31.snippet: In 2017 we need to focus on substance, not celebrity.
2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: The last year has not been the news media’s finest.
2016-12-31.headline_main: Lessons From the Media’s Failures in Its Year With Trump

2016-12-31.abstract: President Obama has had an impressive run of initiatives that assure him of a lofty perch in the environmental pantheon.
2016-12-31.snippet: President Obama has had an impressive run of initiatives that assure him of a lofty perch in the environmental pantheon.
2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: When historians get around to measuring President Obama’s record of protecting America’s public lands from commercial development — its national monuments, parks, forests, wilderness and wildlife refuges — they are likely to rank him high on a list of luminaries that includes both Roosevelts, Jimmy Carter and Bill Clinton. What makes this all the more remarkable is that Mr. Obama came to office as a Chicago urbanite with no obvious passion for environmental stewardship, had no help from Congress and, for his first four years, made little use of his executive authority to protect the federal estate from commercial encroachment. Indeed, his second inaugural address said a great deal about using those lands to produce energy and very little about conservation.
2016-12-31.headline_main: Monuments Man

2016-12-31.abstract: Sudoku isn’t enough. You have to push yourself.
2016-12-31.snippet: Sudoku isn’t enough. You have to push yourself.
2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: Think about the people in your life who are 65 or older. Some of them are experiencing the usual mental difficulties of old age, like forgetfulness or a dwindling attention span. Yet others somehow manage to remain mentally sharp. My father-in-law, a retired doctor, is 83 and he still edits books and runs several medical websites.
2016-12-31.headline_main: How to Become a ‘Superager’

2016-12-31.abstract: During a phone call on the night of Oct. 22, 1968, Richard M. Nixon told his closest aide (and future chief of staff) H.R. Haldeman to "monkey wrench" President Lyndon B. Johnson's efforts to begin peace negotiations over the Vietnam War.

2016-12-31.abstract: New evidence proves that Richard Nixon sabotaged peace talk plans in 1968, a move that may be worse than Watergate.
2016-12-31.snippet: New evidence proves that Richard Nixon sabotaged peace talk plans in 1968, a move that may be worse than Watergate.
2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: Richard M. Nixon always denied it: to David Frost, to historians and to Lyndon B. Johnson, who had the strongest suspicions and the most cause for outrage at his successor’s rumored treachery. To them all, Nixon insisted that he had not sabotaged Johnson’s 1968 peace initiative to bring the war in Vietnam to an early conclusion. “My God. I would never do anything to encourage” South Vietnam “not to come to the table,” Nixon told Johnson, in a conversation captured on the White House taping system.
2016-12-31.headline_main: Nixon’s Vietnam Treachery

2016-12-31.abstract: This past year was a reminder of how little any of us can anticipate.
2016-12-31.snippet: This past year was a reminder of how little any of us can anticipate.
2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: The secret to happiness in almost any relationship is knowing what not to say. Ask your new love about her old loves and you’ll learn more than you want to know, and hear things you’ll never be able to unhear. Start telling your teacher that your dog ate your homework while your grandma was being rushed to the hospital, and he’ll have even less patience with you than if you just say, “I blew it.”
2016-12-31.headline_main: What Do We Know?

2016-12-31.lead_paragraph: BURSA, Turkey — At least 39 people were killed and dozens more were wounded when a single gunman attacked a crowded Istanbul nightclub about an hour after midnight on New Year’s Day, Turkish officials said.
